WASHINGTON, April 30 The Federal Power Commission issued a staff report today asserting that the nation would gain by ending price regulation on natural gas, even though the action would mean higher gas bills for consumers.

In a relaxed and reminiscent talk to about 100 builders and landlords yesterday, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said that while the city's housing problems had grown since he left office 10 years ago, their nature was basically the same.

TRENTON, April 30 (UPI) Governor Byrne named a group of executives, lawyers, economists and labor leaders today to develop a comprehensive plan for stimulating the state's stagnating economy.

WASHINGTON, April 30 Manufacturers finally succeeded in cutting top-heavy inventories in March, the first reduction since August, 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.
The stock market, spurred by a late rally, made a sharp advance yesterday in somewhat heavier trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at its highest level in 10 months.

A judge yesterday drew a disctinction between rape and seduction and found that a man could be crafty, scheming, manipulative and deceitful and use any other method short of force, threat or violence to bed a woman, without being guilty of rape.

Elida Webb Dawson, a dancer and choreographer at the Cotton Club in Harlem from 1923 to 1934, died early yesterday morning at the Park West Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 746 St. Nicholas Ave nue.

The police said last night that they arrested a 26-year-old parolee who had been linked to atleast 12 robberies of doctors and physicians in the last year in the Morrisania and High Bridge sections of the Bronx.
Charles J. Solomon, one of the leading figures in the world of contract bridge, died in Philadelphia yesterday morning after a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

KANSAS CITY, May 1(AP) --Seton Hall University has been placed on probation for two years by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which cited the school for questionable ethical conduct and improper recruiting and financial aid for basketball players.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger said today that United States Navy ships, which had been picking up refugees fleeing by small boats, had left the coast of South Vietnam.

NEWARK, May 1-- Several hundred high-school students demonstrated today in front of City Hall and the Board of Education building here to protest the impending dismissal of more than 1,600 public-school teachers, administrators and workers--20 per cent of the school payroll--and the curtailing of curricular and extracurricular programs.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 1-- Brandeis University officials went into court today in hopes of ousting students who have taken over the school's sociology building in a budget dispute. The move came after negotiations between students and the administration broke down this morning.

The agreement by Mayor Beame and Governor Carey to reduce motor vehicle pollution here comes like a breath of fresh air--figuratively and literally--to a city that has suffered too long from the injurious effects of the internal combustion engine.

TRENTON, May 1 (UPI)-- Government Byrne asked the Federal Government today to set up five regional health service areas in the state. Mr. BMyrne said all of New Jersey's 21 counties should be placed in regional districts within the state not absorbed in metropolitan districts with out-of-state cities.

LOS ANGELES, May 1-- The board of directors of the fiscally troubled Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions will meet in Santa Barbara on May 10 to resolve the fate of the California based study center.
LAS VEGAS, Nev.--Marvin Camel, 174 pounds, Missoula, Mont., knocked out Armado Vasquez, 174 , Las Vegas, 3 rounds.
WASHINGTON, May 1(AP) --President Ford told five new members of the National Consumer Advisory Council today that American consumers needed help in "two critical areas" --price and quality.

For Bruce Crawford, newly elected president of BBDO International, much of the fun of the ad business comes from problem solving--discovering what lies behind a given condition.

SAN DIEGO, May 1--Praise for President Ford's proposal to release the oil industry from the Government's only remaining price controls was coupled today at the Mobil Oil Corporation's annual meeting with a warning to Congress against further "puntive actions."
John Leonard, who has been editor of The New York Times Book Review since 1970, will leave that post to become the newspaper's chief cultural correspondent.
ALBANY, May 1 (UPI)-- Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak said today she would trim her $60,000 annual salary by $3,750.
BOSTON, May 1(AP)--The Massachusetts Senate sustained today a veto of a bill providing the death penalty for nine kinds of murder, thus defeating the measure.
Richard H. Rich, a member of the Atlanta family that founded Rich's Department Store in 1867, died yesterday in Houston. He was 73 years old.
Last Sunday a couple living in the Inwood section in upper Manhattan walked out of the Roman Catholic Church of Good Shepherd after services and was immediately greeted by a stranger.

MONTREAL, May 1(UPI) --Guy Lafleur scored three goals and Ken Dryden earned his second playoff career shutout as the Montreal Canadiens routed Buffalo, 7-0, tonight, narrowing the Sabres' lead to 2-1 in their Stanley Cup semifinal series.
DAMASCUS, Syria, May 1 (Reuters)--Syria withdrew today from an Arab League meeting that has been trying to resolve a dispute between Syria and Iraq over sharing of water from the Euphrates River.

Three prominent theologians of the major faiths agreed yesterday that relations between Jews and Christians had improved in the last year but they expressed concern that a hard core of anti-Jewish sentiment still remained.

TEL AVIV, May 1(AP)-- Finland and Austria won gold medals today in the opening events of the 10th Hapoel Games, organized by the Israeli trade union movement.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The House of Representatives overwhelmingly rejected today a bill that would have authorized $327-million in aid for Vietnamese refugees as the Administration reported that the number of those refugees had swelled by 10,000 to 84,000.
The New York Post is increasing its news-stand price on Monday by 5 cents to 25 cents a copy.

WASHINGTON, May 1-- Senator Jacob K. Javits is trying to restore the flow of gifts by writers, composers and other creative artists of their own works to the Li brary of Congress, museums, universities and other institutions.

Next Tuesday, in the third citywide Community School Boards election, voters will pick the 288 citizens to be entrusted with stewardship over New York's 32 decentralized school districts. This is a decision of utmost importance to the quality of the schools, which in turn has much to do with the quality of the city.

The Bancroft Prizes, given annually by Columbia University, were awarded last night to Stanley L. Engerman and Robert W. Fogel, authors of "Time on the Cross," the twovolume study of American slavery; Eugene D. Genovese, author of another slavery work, "Roll, Jordan, Roll," and Alexander L. George and Richard Smoke, who wrote "Deterrence in American Foreign Policy: Theory and Practice."

Governor Carey's refusal to accept the recommendation of a fact-finding panel for an across-the-board increase of 6 per cent to state employes reflects the painful realities of the fiscal squeeze confronting the state and city governments.
WASHINGTON, N.C., May 1 (AP)--A state judge today ordered the murder trial of Joanne Little moved away from here to Raleigh, in Wake County.

BALTIMORE--Workers in American factories live under a sophisticated kind of dictatorship legitimated by socalled collective-bargaining agreements and policed by collaborationist unions. It is a dictatorship that subordinates workers and makes them vulnerable, in part by keeping them ignorant.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI) --President Ford's Wife, Betty, underwent a cancer check-up today, and doctors found everything "completely normal," a White House spokesman said. Mrs. Ford underwent surgery in September for removal of her right breast. A spokesman for Mrs. Ford said that she had undergone her periodic postsurgery check-up at the Bethesda Naval Hospital.

ANDERSEN AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, Friday, May 2-- The refugee airlift, which four days ago was hauling as many South Vietnamese as possible to this small Pacific island, is now carrying away more than 2,500 people a day toward new lives in the continental United States.

MEXICO CITY, May 1-- The fourth-seeded pair of Arthur Ashe and Tom Okker ousted John Alexander and Phil Dent, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6, 6-3, today in the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis doubles tournament.

The stock market ended higher yesterday in accelerated trading as Wall Street began a new era of competition in brokerage rates. Yesterday was the first time in 183 years that the nation's brokerage houses operated without fixed commission rates.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 1 --Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain urged the nations of the Commonwealth today to support his proposals for stabilizing the prices of food and raw materials through a general agreement on commodities, to which producer and consumer nations would adhere.

HARTFORD, May 1--Two leading Connecticut political figures, along with 250 other healthy people around the state, spent most of the day today in wheelchairs to dramatize problems encountered by the handicapped.

TRENTON, May 1--A state grand jury investigating alleged corruption in Camden County today indicted James Joyce, the Democratic county chairman there and one of New Jersey's most powerful political leaders, on charges of bribery and misconduct in office.
The United Aircraft Corporation said yesterday that it has changed its name, effective immediately, to the United Technologies Corporation.

A new corporation, Concert Radio, Inc., yesterday filed with the Federal Communications Commission a competing application for the license to operate the rock station WQIVFM, with the proposal to return it to its previous classical format under its original call let ters of WNCN-FM.

Dr. William J. McGill, president of Columbia University, who had suggested a review of his five years in office, has been asked by the trustees to continue with what was described as "a warm handshake of confidence from all."

The nation's money supply fell $1-billion in the week ended April 23--a substantial one-week decline--and thereby showed an annual growth rate of 4 per cent, the slowest in six weeks.
American business has lowered its sights this year in capital investment for new plants and equipment, the McGraw-Hill Publications Company said yesterday.

LONDON, May 1 (Reuters)-- Britain's law lords have ruled that a man cannot be convicted of rape if he honestly believed the woman had consented to sexual intercourse--no matter how unreasonable his belief might have been.

Paul A. Volcker, the outspoken pragmatist who managed the country's international monetary relations for five turbulent years from 1969 until 1974 as Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, was formally named yesterday to head the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. His job is the second most powerful position in the central banking system.

Amid some confusion, a considerable amount of gentlemanly horse trading and occasional secrecy, Mayday came to Wall Street quietly yesterday. For the first time in almost 200 years, on the direct orders of the Securities and Exchange Commission, stockbrokers abandoned fixed commission rates.

LONDON, May 1--A consumer stampede for kitchen appliances, phonographs, fur coats, television sets, cigarettes and wines and liquors ended today as sweeping tax increases aimed at balancing the Government's budget went into effect.

A contract, which will give them an 18 per cent pay in crease over the next two years, was approved last night by the unionized em ployes of the American Stock Exchange. The first year's increase will be 12 per cent; the second's, 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $1.06-billion, up 4 per cent from the yearearlier $1.01-billion. Total retail store sales were about $11billion, up 8 per cent from $10.1-billion.
The new Communist rulers of South Vietnam announced yesterday that their forces had completed the take-over of all areas of resistance that had remained after the surrender of Saigon Wednesday.

OTTAWA, May 1--The House of Commons has approved a controversial bill to raise the salaries and allowances of members of both houses of Parliament by one third, putting the Federal lawmakers in a higher income bracket than all but a thin upper layer of Canadian wage earners.

Contracts for new construction in March rose from the February level but were still 15 per cent under the volume of March, 1974, the F.W. The Government of Greece has now indicated clearly that it will not permit resentment over United States behavior during the Cyprus tragedy of 1974 to destroy the links with this country that are vital for Greek security. WASHINGTON, May 1-- Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, will ask Gov. Calvin L. Rampton of Utah to clarify a statement made to the committee yesterday that 49 of the Governors in office in the last two years supported the nomination of Stanley K. Hathaway to be Secretary of the Interior.

ALBANY, May 1--The move to stop the proposed women's rights amendment picked up momentum today as the state Conservative party announced its support of an alternative measure that would, in effect, keep the amendment off the referendum ballot next November.
CHICAGO, May 1 (UPI)--A Federal jury returned a split decision today on the two prime suspects in the $4.3-million burglary of Purolator Inc., the ]argest cash theft in U.S. history.

FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., May 1 --Though some local residents oppose housing even a small number of Vietnamese refugees on this Army post, a State Department official said today, that the exiles with the toughest resettlement problems might be sent here.

RIDGEWOOD, May 1--Students from this affluent white suburb and a predominantly Spanish-speaking and black neighborhood of the Bronx completed an exchange of school visits today and decided that they had more in common than they had imagined.

WASHINGTON, May 1--As sociate Justice Thurgood Marshall said tonight that he opposed all the varying plans that would ease the Supreme Court's workload by creating a new national court of appeals to share the judicial burden.
The Secretary of Labor, John T. Dunlop, said yesterday that the jobless rate would not go "much higher" than the 8.7 per cent level reported for March before it peaked.

Ten living journalists were named yesterday by the New York Chapter of Sigma Delta Chi to the professional society's Hall of Fame. The selection is part of the group's 50th anniversary, which the New York chapter will observe with a dinner on May 20.
DETROIT, May 1--The Chrysler Corporation reported today a net loss of $94.1-million for the first quarter of 1974, the company's largest loss for any quarter in its history.

Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it was raising its regular quarterly dividend on common stock to 27 cents a share from 25 cents. The dividend is payable July 1 to shareholders of record May 30.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 1 (AP)--The United States Government has agreed to a substantial withdrawal of American forces from Thailand, Foreign Minister Chatichai Choonhavan said at a news conference today.

Nixon to President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam in 1972 and 1973 spurted new demands in the Senate today for a full disclosure by the Ford Administration of all private documents relating to possible American commitments to Saigon.

BLUE HILL, Me., April 30--The men and women who follow the arcane science of demography became aware recently that a significant change had taken place in the State of Maine. It had begun to gain population after decades of losing people.

YONKERS, May 1--The owners of Young Quinn, said to be the fastest harness horse of the Southern Hemisphere since Cardigan Bay, have accepted an invitation to Yonkers Raceway's first International Pace since 1971, Timothy Rooney, Yonkers president announced today.

TRENTON, May 1--A state grand jury investigating alleged corruption in Camden County today indicted James Joyce, the Democratic county chairman there and one of New Jersey's most powerful political leaders, on charges of bribery and misconduct in office.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 1--A senior member of South Korea's ruling party said today that President Park Chung Hee's restrictive political policies had failed to achieve the intended national unity but asserted that they still represented the best course.
LUANDA, Angola, May 1 (Reuters)--Sporadic shooting broke out in Luanda for the third day today among rival liberation groups.
Spirits have been restored at the main bar at the Harvard Club. The 8-to-1 martinis are back.

The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company (Corco) lost a legal move yesterday to stop the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation from completing its tender offer for 38 per cent of Corco's stock next Tuesday.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 1-- Responding to a deteriorating economic situation in this oncebooming area, John V.N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, today presented a $700-million capital program that proposed a moratorium on new projects for the county during the next three years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 --The educated guesses as to the size of the Kentucky Derby field, "between 13 and 15," turned out to be sound indeed. When the draw for post position was made this morning for the 1 -mile clas sic, 15 names were put into the entry box.

CLEVELAND, May 1 (UPI) --Everett L. White, 34 years old, of Cadiz, Ohio, was arrested here yesterday, by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who charged him with air piracy in the hijacking of an Eastern Airlines passenger plane to Cuba on Jan. 28, 1969. The F.B.I. said Mr. White returned to the United States recently from Cuba after six years and had been living with a brother in Cleveland Heights.

The General Dynamics Corporation realized a first-quarter earnings increase of 88 per cent, "but we do not anticipate that increase will continue throughout the year," David S. Lewis, chairman, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in St. Louis.

DETROIT, May 1--American auto production totaled 590,463 units last month, off 12.9 per cent from the 677,748 cars built in April, 1974, and the lowest for any April in 14 years.

ALBANY, May 1--Chief Judge Charles D. Breitel of the Court of Appeals, charging that recent legislative action on court reform has been dangerous, undesirable and replete with "obvious defects," said today that he would soon propose an entire new judiciary article for the State Constitution.

SEAFORD, Del., May 1 (UPI) --E. I. duPont de Nemours Co., Inc., said 142 employes at a local nylon plant returned to work today in the first callback of workers laid off in recent months. BONN, May 2 West Germany has approved a major accord with Brazil under which Bonn will receive long-term deliveries of natural uranium in return for its advanced nuclear technology, a Government spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI) Documents of the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that the Gulf Oil Corporation paid $4.2-million in bribes to foreign politicians to protect the company's oil assets.

WASHINGTON, May 2-The nation's unemployment rate edged up two-tenths of a point in April to 8.9 per cent even though the total number of persons with jobs rose for the first time since last September, the Labor Department reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 Northern California physicians entered the second day of their strike today to protest the high cost of malpractice insurance.

WASHINGTON, May 2 The American Civil Liberties Union called today upon Representative Lucien N. Nedzi to affirm his intention to investigate the activities of American intelligence-gathering organizations or to resign the chairmanship of a House select committee set up for that purpose.

More portable typewriters than office machines are sold in the United States each year, but the prices are lower [from $60 to $300 compared with $300 to $1,000], the profits are smaller and the market is shrinking.

The evolution of the typewriter from a machine operated by hands and feet to one that, without either, zooms along typing 350 words a minute makes automation in the office seem a flick of a switch away. But although explosive growth is predicted for producers engaged in automating paper work, some aspects of today's office--including the need for some people at keyboard--will probably not exchange before the year 2000.

A former employe of a large South Jersey nursing home has reportedly complained to state authorities that 30 of the 60 elderly patients in the home's intensive-care wing died last winter after the home's administrators ignored the recommendations of its own medical consultant to protect the patients from an influenza epidemic.

WASHINGTON, May 4 At least 40 to 50 per cent of veterans who received less than honorable discharges over the last 15 years and some who received them earlier could get their discharges upgraded if they had strong legal representation, a new book by the American Civil Liberties Union contends.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 4 A breach has opened between human rights advocates and the Roman Catholic hierarchy in Chile.

LOS ANGELES, May 4 California officials are grappling with the problem of appeasing around a million irate motorists who spent $35 or more for auto smog control devices under a state law that has just been repealed.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies traded Willie Montanez, a first baseman, to the San Francisco Giants today for Garry Maddox, an outfielder.

LONG BEACH, Calif., May 4 (AP) John Powell, a San Jose, Calif., policeman, smashed the world record in the discus throw by two feet today with a toss of 226 feet 8 inches.

For many, many years the Bolshoi Ballet's production of "Swan Lake," as staged by Asaf Messerer, after (many years after) Petipa, Ivanov and Gorsky, had been widely regarded, at the most charitable view, as obsolescent. In 1969 it was finally declared obsolete in Moscow, and the current new staging by Yuri Grigorovich had its first performance at the Boishoi Theater on Dec. 25 of that year.

PARIS, May 4 (A.P.) Michel Laurent, whose photographs of Bangladesh soldiers executing turncoats after the 1971 IndiaPakistan War won the Pulitzer Prize, was killed April 28 covering one of the last battles in South Vietnam, the Gamma photo agency announced today. Mr. Laurent, a Frenchman, was hit during action between South Vietnamese militamen and Communist troops and died on the spot, the agency said.

MILWAUKEE, May 4 The Milwaukee Brewers completed a three-game sweep of the Yankees today by amassing 16 hits for an 11-4 victory. So the New Yorkers left for Baltimore wondering what went wrong after they finally had begun resembling the pennant contender they were supposed to be.

HOUSTON, May 4 (AP) Bruce Crampton, the pokerfaced Australian, turned back repeated challenges by Dr. Gil Morgan with a carefully constructed 69 and scored a two-stroke victory today in the Houston open golf tournament.

PARAMUS, May 4 A doctor and his wife from Franklin Lakes are delighted over their coming weekend at New York's Plaza Hotel. A business executive is equally elated over his new Lincoln Continental. BOSTON May 4 (AP) Westgate Mall, ridden by Temistocles Santos, beat the Kentucky Derby winner, Jacinto Vasquez, and Onion in the stretch today for a head victory in the $28,350 Bay State Handicap before a crowd of 12,296 at Suffolk Downs.

The State Public Service Commission has made a small but consequential start toward rationalizing Consolidated Edison's rate structure. By a margin of approximately four seconds, Bob Watson of the Houston Astros yesterday scored major league baseball's heavily publicized and eagerly anticipated one millionth run. Taking a shower in New York City could scarcely qualify as an unusual experience, but while doing just that a short time ago, I had what might be described as a vision.

LONDON, May 5 A significant share of the British Petroleum Company may be acquired by West German and Iranian interests as a result of preliminary negotiations that apparently have taken place through intermediaries in the financial community.
Cleon , Jones returned to New York last night following his arrest in St. Petersburg, Fla., where the police said he was found sleeping nude in a station wagon on the main street in town.

CHARLOTTE. N.C., May 5 A jury took just under two hours today to conclude that no constitutional rights had been violated by any of nine defendants accused in a $1-mil-' lion civil suit of systematically and illegally barring antiwar demonstrators from a Billy Graham Day rally attended by President Nixon in 1971.

TRENTON, May 5 The State Senate rejected tonight a bill that would have allowed Prosecutors in the state's 21 counties to establish individual obscenity standards based on detailed guidelines set forth in the proposed statute.

Daniel Barenboim, who will be conducting the New York Philharmonic later this week, preceded his interpretations on the podium with a Carnegie Hall recital last night. Henry Kissinger has told James Reston of The New York Times that he will not resign as Secretary of State. This is good news, if true, but can we rely on it?
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 5 After 20 months in power, the military junta has been unable to brake Chile's inflation, the world's worst, or control the highest unemployment in a generation.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled in Brooklyn yesterday that the refusal by nursing homes officials to admit state safety inspectors was not so serious an offense as to warrant the lifting of their licenses.

PARIS, Tuesday, May 6 (Reuters) A spokesman for South Vietnam's Provisional Revolutionary Government said today that hatred and divisions still persist within South Vietnamese families and these are the first postwar wounds which must be healed.

Among the many excellent environmental recommendations Governor Carey has just made to the Legislature, one of the most important and urgent is the proposal to preserve this state's remaining freshwater wetlands. Caro's controversial and current "The Power Broker: Robert Moses and the Fall of New York," and the first five volumes of "Jefferson and His Time" by Dumas Malone. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said today he believed the nation's economic recovery would be slower than some business leaders have predicted and he forecast that total steel industry shipments this year would lag 15 to 20 per cent below the levels of 1973 and 1974.

WASHINGTON Spurred by the Democratic "freshmen class," the House of Representatives is reforming itself to the point of revolution. In most quarters the news is welcome and long overdue. WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore said in Washington last night that the loss of American allies in Indochina to Communism was an "unmitigated disaster" and that unless the Ford Administration and Congress spoke with one voice in the future, further aggression could not be deterred.
TOKYO, May 9 (AP) China delivered a blistering attack on the Soviet Union today, charging, the Kremlin is "trying to embark on Hitler's beaten track of world domination."

DALLAS, May 11 Arthur Ashe, so often taunted as the "world champion runner-up," won the first prize today as he took the fifth annual World Championship Tennis title in a businesslike victory over Bjorn Borg of Sweden, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4, 6-0.

BOSTON, May 11 Journalism is by nature episodic and ephemeral. Most of what appears in newspapers fades as quickly as the context of events. But there was a piece of work the other day that I think will live, as writing and something more: the set of stories filed by Sydney Schanberg of The New York Times on his emergence from Cambodia.

The United Federation of Teachers appeared yesterday to have won a substantial victory in the third citywide election of community school boards, Candidates backed by the union gained a working majority of seats on at least 21 of the 32 local boards, as the tally of Tuesday's vote continued.

BRUSSELS, May 11 The European Common Market signed a trade treaty with Israel today despite a lastminute Arab demand for a delay until similar accords could be negotiated with three Arab countries, Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia.

FREDERICK, Md., May 11 Walter T. Bonney, director of public affairs for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from its formation in 1958 until 1960, died here last night of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

America's longest and deepest postwar recession has come as a fresh shock to younger executives who climbed to the top in the heady boom years, of the late nineteen-sixties and early seventies. For those who lacked memories of the thirties, business appeared a boundless horizon of carefully managed results.

CHICAGO, May 10 "Philology leads to chaos," remarks a character in Eugene Ionesco's "The Lesson." This observation about linguistics seems tailormade to "Language Celebration," a two-day coloquium" at the University of Chicago that ended yesterday and that included, fittingly, a performance of the Ionesco play, a comedy that satirizes professors as teachers of knowledge.

Newly available census data indicate that the average income for New York City families started going down well hefore the current national recession. A new study estimates an 8.3 per cent plunge from a 1970 peak of $10,951 to $10,039 in 1972.

DALLAS, May 11 Photographs of three shabbily dressed men being led by the police from the scene of the assassination of President Kennedy are being re-examined by a photographic expert for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Readers of the novels of Richard Condon may have wondered why his characters often bear the same names even though the settings and periods of the books are different.
HOBOKEN, May 7 Despite her age, the 14,893-ton S.S. Stevens, the country's only floating dormitory, has successfully spanned the generation gap, only to face the scrap heap.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) Rick Barry scored 36 points, 12 in the game-turning second quarter, as the Golden State Warriors scored an 86-72 victory today over the Chicago Bulls.
State energy officials want consumers to look for the energy efficiency rating when buying an air-conditioner for the summer months.
SEOUL, South Korea The South Korean analyst sat back with an anxious look and said: "Frankly, I am impressed by the sophistication of the training the North Koreans get for a Vietcong-type of war."

TRENTON, May 11 The vender under scrutiny by a State grand jury investigating purchases by the Garden State Parkway was identified by a state law-enforcement official today as the Fire and Municipal Equipment Company of Monmouth County.
Legend has it that the British referred to Princeton University as a "seedbed of revolution" after its sixth president, John Witherspoon, signed the Declaration of Independence.

Probably the ultimate status symbol next fall will be. Elsa Peretti's 18-karat gold mesh bra and corselette belt, the ones that Halston showed with his fall collection on Seventh Avenue. Winning combination, that HalstonPeretti team. You know about her bud vase, diamonds by the yard and other knickknacks. They were all launched on their fashionable careers at Halston shows.

Mayor Beame yesterday termed as "specious" and "legal double talk" the arguments given by Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon for the Federal Government's refusal to grant the city $1.5billion in special assistance.

A 57-year-old art dealer was stabbed to death in his suite at a fashionable hotel on the Upper East Side early yesterday, and a young man with blood on his chest was taken into custody by policemen in the lobby and charged with the murder.

So now we know everything about the Watergate affair except why it happened. And we may never know that because it is doubtful whether even Richard M. Nixon does. All historians can do is to speculate about his reasons for making the choices that he did. They can turn psychoanalysts and try to arrive at these reasons by...

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 11 Nigeria has cut back production of crude oil by almost a quarter since last November. The latest monthly production reports show that Nigerian production is about 1.7 million barrels a day compared with its peak last year of 2.3 million barrels.

That Pete Rose might have been safe at home plate didn't tarnish the Mets' most stirring defensive play of the season. That they made the eighth-inning play and that Umpire John Kibler called Rose out were sufficient to help the Mets beat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, yesterday and snap their six-game losing streak.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 11 Their tutus and the shoes left behind for the day, 90 dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet arrived here in blue jeans and sandals eager to coordinate plies with kicks to a soccer ball.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 9 Engineers who have been workling for years to develop alternatives to the internal combustion engine reported progress there this week, but went away doubting that many people ever would drive cars powered by their radically different engines.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 11 The Laotian capital, braced for disturbances after a week of political and military upheavals, passed a quiet but tense Constitution Day today.

Perhaps it is part of the natural foods movement, "do-it-yourself" era or whatever you may call it, but we have received more requests for homemade sausages during the past year than ever in the history of our career in food reporting.

A 19-year-old youth walking back with friends from a Spanish festival on Randalls Island was fatally injured last night when he vaulted over a low stone wall on the Triborough Bridge unaware that on the other side was a 50-foot drop to a lower roadway. The youth was identified as Dereck Won of 1875 Third Avenue.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 5 After 20 months in power Chile's military junta shows few signs of dismantling the vast apparatus of political repression created to "extirpate the Marxist cancer."

Dominic Barone, the motorman on the last run of Brooklyn's Culver Station saluted its demise at midnight Saturday by blaring the elevated four-car train's shrill horn all along its short trip above 38th Street in Borough Park.

One of the first roles in the New York City Ballet's repertory for which Jean-Pierre Bonnefous displayed a special affinity was the male lead in "Bugaku." He has continued to perform it with distinction, and Saturday evening partnered Suzanne Farrell in a lovely performance at the New York State Theater.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) Hundreds of demonstrators, most of them women and members of the National Organization for Women, picketed the offices of the Apostolic Delegation to the United States today in a "Mother's Day of Outrage" against the Roman Catholic Church's support of anti-abortion legislation.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 11 A seasoned nine-year veteran and green rookie shared the honors today in the second day of the four-day qualifying period for the Indianapolis 500.
ALBANY As lawyers. go, John F. Haggerty and C. Daniel Chill do not seem that high-powered. They sport no Wall Street shingles, no Brooks Brothers outfits, no important Manhattan bar credentials.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 11 The man is short and round, and refugee camp life has not visibly affected his rosy-cheeked vigor.
The new rulers of South Vietnam intend to hold nationwide elections and eventually to unify North and South Vietnam, according to delayed news dispatches from Saigon.
UNIONDALE, L.I., May 11 The New York Islanders were wearing the biggest smile this side of Montauk following their 2-1 victory over the Stanley Cup champions, Philadelphia Flyers, today.
The most detailed assessment to date of the engineering, medical, dietary, agricultural and political problems in establishing a colony in space was carried out last week at Princeton University.
BERLIN, May 11 (Reuters) -The Mayor of West Berlin accused East German authorities tonight of inhumanity after a 5-year-old Turkish boy drowned in the River Spree within East German territory.

A motorist who stopped his car on the Grand Central Parkway early yesterday afternoon because it was overheating discovered an explosive device wired to the motor and gasoline tank. The ensuing police investigation stopped traffic for an hour on the Queens thoroughfare.

The cost of sabbatical leaves granted to City University faculty members has more than doubled in four years, from $2.4-million in 1970 to $5.5-million in 1974, because of a "disproportionate increase" in approval of such leaves by the member colleges, the State Controller's office said yesterday.

UNIONDALE, L.I., May 11 Successfully walking the tightrope again in their death-defying act, the New York Islanders defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 2-1, today and tied their four-ofseven-game National Hockey League semifinal series.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 5 After 20 months in power Chile's military junta shows few signs of dismantling the vast apparatus of political repression created to "extirpate the Marxist cancer."
Total shipments of metal powders in 1974 fell 16 per cent to 290,760 tons, Kempton H. Roll, executive director of the Metals Powders Industries Federation, announced over the weekend.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The Supreme Court returns to the bench tomorrow for the homestretch drive of the 1974-75 term, with nearly half its cases for the year still to be decided.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 11 Dr. Alexander Comfort, the British gerontologist and author of the best-selling book "Joy of Sex," said today that he was instructing his attorneys to take legal action against the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions following its decision yesterday to dismantle most of its, academic programs and relocate much of what remained to Chicago.

PARIS, May 11 Western oil specialists see China developing as one of the world's biggest oil-producing and exporting nations by the end of this decade, and possibly joining the cartel of oil states known as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 Harvard crews won five of six final events today at the Eastern sprint championships on Lake Carnegie and the varsity eight broke a record in the process. This undefeated crew beat five rivals in the heavyweight final, leading all the way through the 2,000-meter (1.23 miles) course, and finished in the remarkable time of 5 minutes 43.6 seconds.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 This city's gigantic Bicentennial festival, "The American Way," was conducted under cloudless skies in balmy spring weather today, with the result that predictions of crowds up to one million appeared to have been met or exceeded.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Alexander P. Butterfield, who disclosed the existence of the White House tapes, said today he believed that President Nixon had prior knowledge of the first Watergate break-in.
A 16-year-old Bronx girl died, apparently of smoke inhalation, yesterday despite efforts by Fireman Dennis Smith, the author of "Report From Engine Company 82," to revive her.

ROME, May 11 Italy is uneasily questioning the nature of a new leftist terrorist organization, the Armed Proletarian Units, that engineered the kidnapping of a high judge and a prison revolt last week amid increasing tension in the country.

TREASURE The Public Library labels its new exhibition, "Swiss Horizon," one of its largest and most unusual in some time. The three-part display of Swiss art, history and culture is on view in the Library's central building, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. Monday through Saturday from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. through June 15.

LANDOVER, Md., May 11 The Washington Bullets beat the Celtics in every phase of the game today and ended Boston's reign as the National Basketball Association champion 364 days after it began in Milwaukee.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 11 Niki Lauda, wet from rain and sweat, somewhat dazed and slightly exhausted, gave Ferrari its first victory in the Monaco Grand Prix in 20 years today. The wealthy Austrian easily finished ahead of Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, the world driving champion.
A Roman Catholic priest, a rabbi and a Protestant minister yesterday shared the pulpit for the first time at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 55th Street.

The marriage of Meryl Elaine Wiener, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Wiener of Brooklyn, to Barry Alan Bryer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bryer of Bellerose, Queens, took place here yesterday afternoon.

Mayor Beame yesterday termed as "specious" and "legal double talk" the arguments given by Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon for the Federal Government's refusal to grant the city $1.5billion in special assistance.
BOSTON, May 11 (UPI) Harold Kaese, who retired in 1973 as sports columnist and writer for The Boston Globe, died yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 66 years old.

LONDON, May 11?The sharply falling value of the pound on the world currency markets has aroused deep concern in the British Government, but apparently no decision has been made to try to halt the slide.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 11 (AP) Britain and the Mozambique Liberation Front agreed today that peace and security in southern Africa, including Rhodesia, can be achieved only "when the fundamental rights of the people to freedom and independence are guaranteed."

NEW DELHI, May 11 India, a nation whose experiment in democracy once served as a major source of study on American campuses, is witnessing a rapid decline of interest among teachers and students in the United States.

Seventy-five feet under the heart of Paris a complex tunneling project will link three sections of a five-year-old regional rail express network that already carries twice as many commuters as the Long Island Rail Road.

WASHINGTON What if every man, woman and child who lived on Manhattan Island were told: "Get out of town. Today, on pain of death. No excuses. Start walking and don't stop until you get to farmland upstate or in Pennsylvania. When you get there, if you do, you're on your own."

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., May 11 The top-winning bulldog bitch in the history of the breed in America. Ch. Westfield Cunomorus Stone, added another victory to her list today. She was named best of l,461 dogs at Windham County's 31st show on Recreation Field. It was an exceptionally strong final, with all six dogs having been bestin-show performers.

APRA HARBOR, Guam, Monday, May 12 The aircraft carrier Midway arrived today to unload a controversial cargo of 99 repossessed South Vietnamese military aircraft. Meanwhile, the curtailment of refugee flights to the United States continued.

NEWARK, May 11 A spokesman for the city's Board of Education said today that groups of parents, students and community representatives were scheduling a march that would converge on City Hall and the board's headquarters in the heart of the business district tomorrow morning to protest planned mass layoffs of teachers.

In nine years of pitching for the Los Angeles Dodgers, Don Sutton has never been able to reach the goal that signifies stardom, a 20-victory season. He has come close in the last three campaigns, winning 19 in 1972, 18 in 1973 and 19 last year.

Arthur Lehmeier, a former vice president of the Detecto Scales Corporation and later Eastern sales manager for BorgErickson Corporaticn, scale manufacturers, died Saturday at the Veterans Administration Hospital, the Bronx. He was 85 years old and lived in Cortland, N.Y.

FARMINGTON, Cenn., May 11-Harmony Farm's Vesuvius, ridden-by Alan Severison scored sn easy victory in the amateur-owned jumper division today at the concluding session of the Children's Services Horse Show.
TEL AVIV, May 11 Saboteurs derailed an Israeli freight train approaching Jerusalem early today, injuring the engineer and his assistant.

NEWARK, May 11 The Institute for Public Transportation, a nonprofit research organization, has sharply criticized the transportation recommendations made last month by Governor Byrne's Commission to Evaluate the Capital Needs of New Jersey.

Ruth Janeway Gordon, a stockbroker with Edwards Hanly, died Saturday at her home, 205 West 57th Street. Her age was 75.

TRENTON, May 11 The New Jersey State School Boards Association voted yesterday to seek the repeal of a law requiring local school boards to supply free textbooks to nonpublic-school students.
LOS ANGELES, May 11 President Nixon's plan for salling 10 million acres of offshore oil rights this year is becoming steadily more problematical and could end up with no 1975 leasing at all.

Jane Leslie Weston, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel Halperin of Lawrence, L.I., and Lawrence G. Weston of South Amboy, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Barry Roy Linsky. He is the son of John Linsky of Miami Beach and the late Mrs. Linsky. Rabbi Mark N. Goldman performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

Edward J. Beach, vice president of the Abbe Engineering Company and an officer of the Beach Russ Company, both of Brooklyn, who held a number of patents relating to vacuum pumps, died Saturday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

Andrew Bololowsky's program Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, his third there in three years, was engagingly lightweight and offbeat. The flutist's partner was Robert Shaughnessy, guitarist and composer, and at the end, Janc Adler, a mime, performed to a seven-part suite, "Cosmic Park," by Mr. Shaughnessy.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 11 (AP) The new Government of Cambodia today stressed its strong ties with China and thanked North Vietnam and North Korea for their support in "defeating the U.S. imperialists."

YONKERS, May 11 The temperature was in the low 70's and long-distance runners prefer cooler weather, which accounted for the slow times today in the Yonkers marathon, won by Marty Sudzina in 2 hours 27 minutes 37.2 seconds.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 11 Catfish Hunter proved a tough act for the New York Yankees to follow today. With their prosperous prodigal watching from the dugout, they were mauled for six runs in the third inning and never fully recovered as the Oakland's A's swept to a 7-5 victory.

For decades New Yorkers have been pedaling bikes around the Central Park lake. Now they can pedal right across with the park's latest item for recreation this spring: six shiny yellow paddle boats.

HUNTINGTON, W.Va., May 11 (UPI) Ella Hatfield, whose marriage to Charles McCoy in 1898 sent shock waves through the feuding families of Hatfields and McCoys in the mountains of West Virginia and Kentucky, died Friday at her home here. She was 98 years old.

More than eight months after news articles disclosed that the Children's Center, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, was being terrorized by adolescent girl residents and by young hoodlums who gathered outside, there has been considerable improvement at the institution.

WASHINGTON, May 12 After marking time for more than a year, Federal Trade Commission lawyers are about to resume questioning of oil-industry executives in a major antitrust case involving the country's eight largest oil companies.

The Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, Inc., said yesterday that the Administration's goal of 200 nuclear power plants by 1985 is too high, while its projection of an oil import level of 4.7 million barrels a day is too low.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The chairman of a House subcommittee has charged that the State Department's efforts on behalf of an oil company under investigation for violatinn Federal price and customs laws was "an unwarranted intrusion" into the normal processes of law enforcement.

WNET/13 and the Public Broadcasting Service both said yesterday that they would proceed with the scheduled telecast next Monday of a Swedishmade documentary on Manhattan's Harlem, in spite of vociferous objections to the film by a number of prominent blacks.

Grown to 57 members in its second season, the Riverside Orchestra has dropped the "chamber" from its title, acquired additional state funding and expanded its primary activity of giving free concerts at schools, settlement houses, senior citizen homes and parks. Under the galvanizing direction of Larry Newland, an assistant coductor at the New York Philharmonic, this semiprofessional ensemble is a shining example of how good a community orchestra can be.

C.B. (Beanie) Baldwin, a New Deal official undo President Franklin D. Roosevelt and campaign manager for Henry A. Wallace in the 1948 Presidential campaign, died yesterday of cancer in Bethesda, Md. He was 72 years old and lived in Kent, Conn.
Bobby Murcer returned to New York Last night, but it was a boy from Brooklyn who provided the excitement at Shea Stadium.
TRENTON, May 12 (UPI) The state argued before the Supreme Court today that all shotguns and rifles should be registered, not just those bought after the gun-control law passed in 1966.

Possession of the six of hearts and the considerable skill that brought him two world titles five years ago gave victory in the prestigious Cavendish Charity Invitation Pairs here Sunday night to Jim Jacoby of Dallas.

BOSTON, May 12-The first Russian warships to visit an American port since the end of World War II tied up here today. LENINGRAD, May 12-Two United States warships eased into the Neva River mouth today and became the first American men-of-war to visit the Soviet Union since 1945.
The Celtics need reinforcements for next season. The Boston practice of adding a player, usually from the college draft, and bringing him along slowly, won't do.
One of the city's few skywalks; a kind of Buck Rogers-era span between skyscrapers in lower Manhattan, was demolished yesterday because it was losing one of its skyscrapers.
Three indictments against Herbert Itkin, a 48-year-old informer, were dismissed yesterday. Mr. Itkin helped convict a number of public officials, union officers and members of organized crime.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art opened its resplendent and controversial new addition last night, the Lehman Collection, with a private viewing for 600 "friends of the Lehman Foundation."

OTTAWA-A substantial increase in Canadian defense spending in the next fiscal year is likely to take the form of greater emphasis on sea and air forces and a reduction of the role of ground-force units in Europe.

The first tenant in the shiny steel Olympic Tower building at 51st Street and Fifth Avenue is the wildly colorful boutique, Roberta di Camerino, which is spreading around the world from its beginning in Venice after World War II.
BOSTON, May 12 (UPI) Charles W. Colson, the former Nixon aide, today asked a Massachusetts court to let him practice law.

WASHINGTON, May 12-The military, forced by Congress to reduce its number of enlisted servants, is proposing to set up what Senator William Proxmire describes as a $1-million "pamper fund" to provide housecleaning and catering services for servantless generals and admirals.

WASHINGTON, May 12-The White House announced today that a Cambodian naval vessel fired on a United States merchant ship in international waters in the Gulf of Siam early this morning and forced it into the Cambodian port of Sihanoukville.

Vandals burned three classrooms and ransacked 20 others in Community School 6 in the West Farms section of the Bronx early yesterday morning, causing damage estimated at $100,000 and forcing the transfer of 300 students to other classrooms, school officials said.

In the first TV commercials it has made for the Irving Trust Company since 1971, J. Walter Thompson changes mannequins into bank employes.

CHUNCHULA, Ala., May 10 When the lease buyer from the oil company came down the road one morning a couple of years ago, Ed Gwinn was more than happy to sell him the mineral rights to a 20-acre patch of scrub pine.

SACRAMENTO, Calif. May 12 (AP) Teamster leaders said today that there would be an industrywide agricultural strike in four states July 15 if Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s secret ballot farm labor bill was enacted.
DALLAS, May 12 (AP) Tom Watson turned back Jack Ewing with a solid sixunder-par 65 today and scored a two-stroke victory in the rain-delayed $175,000 Byron Nelson golf classic.

QUEBEC, May 12 (AP) The Houston Aeros, led by the father-son combination of Gordie and Mark Howe, defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 7-2, tonight and captured their second consecutive World Hockey Association championship. The Aeros took four straight games.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Mayor Beame and Governor Carey will take their appeal for S1.5-billion in emergency financial assistance for New York City directly to President Ford tomorrow, but White House sources said privately today that they would almost certainly be turned down.
KUWAIT, May 12-President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt arrived in this muggy oil port on the Persian Gulf today on the first leg of a 10-day tour that will take him also to Iraq, Jordan and Syria.
MANILA, May 12 (AP)-A 26-year-old American who was arrested in 1972 on charges of having participated in a plot to kill President Ferdinand E. Marcos denied the charge today.
BONN, May 12-Volkswagen, the leading symbol of West Germany's postwar "economic miracle," announced today a less of $336-million in its worldwide operations for 1974.
The Jefferson Starship (formerly the Jefferson Airplane) opened the local summer season for pop music yesterday afternoon with a free concert on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

A paradox exists. There is compassion for Vietnamese children, Cambodian children, Korean children, while children in our population are invisible, ignored, abused. We talk of children's rights, assign law guardians to represent their interests in the courts, yet curtail lunch programs, limit educational opportunities, eliminate housing resources, But even more than that, in some places we turn the family structure upside down. We make the child the wage earner and the parent the dependent.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP)Machinists and aerospace workers have voted to return to work at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, ending a 12-week strike that put 11,500 employes out of work.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 12 (Reuters) Bolivia accepted today the word of the Gulf Oil Corporation that it did not bribe government officials here, but insisted on a full investigation of "political contributions" the company says it might have paid.

WASHINGTON, May 12 A global picture of what conditions of life must have been like for humans during the last great ice age is emerging from computer studies of the climate largely sponsored by the National Science Foundation.

Mike Marshall, the Los Angeles Dodgers' tireless relief pitcher who won the National League's Cy Young Award in 1974 after appearing in 106 games, has been placed on the 21-day disabled list, retroactive to May 10. He will be eligible to pitch again on May 31.

PARIS, Way 12. The French Government announced today that it would merge the nation's troubled computer producer with its rival Honeywell-Bull after the Americancontrolled company sold a controlling interest to French Government and private interests.
WASHINGTON, May 12--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, moving with unusual speed, approved today legislation to aid Indochina refugees after limiting the program's cost to $405-million.
Dresser Industries, Inc., reported yesterday an increase of 140 per cent in earnings for the quarter ended April 30.

Joe Mooney, a jazz pianist, organist, accordionist and singer who had an intensely loyal following among his fellow musicians, died yesterday at Las Olas Hospital in tFort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 65 years old.
Demand for Treasury debt issues was strong yesterday, with aggressive buyers bidding up prices throughout the maturity list. By comparison, the corporate and tax-exempt bond...
An 80-year-old man was kicked and beaten early yesterday by a young mugger who jumped him outside his home in Great Neck. L.I., and stole $150 despite the man's efforts to ward him off with a cane.

"I have never in my life spent fuller days, but strangely I've never been less tired," said Alex Kroll, managing director of Young Rubicam, U.S.A., manager of the New York office and creative director of Young Rubicam International worldwide.

With American Telephone and Telegraph Company warrants expiring on Thursday, a number of stockholders have moved to exercise their warrants to buy the stock at $52 a share even though the price still hovers a fraction below the critical level.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 12 (AP) Seniors at Seton Hall Preparatory School reported for classes today with trimmed hair following their headmaster's ultimatum to shed long locks or face suspension a month before graduation.

WASHINGTON, May 12- The 23-nation Organization of American States reached agreement today on meeting in Costa Rica later this year to consider lifting its 11-year-old embargo against Cuba.

Mayor Beame said yesterday that the three-week-old crackdown on illegal parkers and scofflaws had resulted in the highest collections of fines in the history of the Parking Violations Bureau.

WASHINGTON, May 12-The House Ways and Means Committee, deeply divided over how best to handle the nation's energy problems, approved today legislation that would raise the Federal tax on gasoline and take other steps designed to conserve fuel.

Murray Davis, who was a newspaper investigative reporter before that specialty became widespread, died Sunday in the Sands Point (L.I.) Nursing Home after a stroke. His age was 72.He lived on Harbor Road in Sands Point.

Dr. Charles Vaurie, curator emeritus of the department of ornithology at the American Museum of Natural History, died yesterday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived in Reading, Pa.

BETHPAGE, L.I., May 15 The chairman of the Grumman Corporation said at the company's annual meeting today that the company had resolved its financial troubles over the production of the controversial F14 Tomcat fighter plane and that Grumman expected to make profits on forthcoming deliveries of the jet to the United States Navy and to Iran. The journalism department of Long Island University anpounced yesterday it was giving a special George Polk Memorial award to Sydney H. Schanberg, the correspondent of The New York Times who remained in Cambodia to report on the fall of Phnom Penh to the Khmer Rouge.
The New York Telephone Company is planning to put 2,000 of its 5,800 telephone operators in the five boroughs an a four-day work week at four days' pay beginning July 6 because of a drop in business.

PEKING, Friday, May 16 China, in her first official reaction to the American military operation that recaptured the container ship Mayagues, last night branded it "an outright act of piracy that should be strongly condemned by world opinion."

Why not, indeed and, to be as enigmatic as Mr. Balanchine, this may or may not be the question to which the City Ballet will be unwittingly providing the answer over this and the two successive weekends.

PARIS Overnight, by resolute and skillful leadership in the Mayaguez crisis, President Ford has seemingly moved from the doldrums of Hooverdom toward the vigor of Harry Truman. He made up his mind; he consulted political leaders; he acted; and he succeeded. Small as the incident may later seem in history, a polluting stain is being erased from the previous American image of lassitude, uncertainty and pessimism.

ROME, May 18 Italy is bracing for a week-long wave of strikes that will disrupt transportation and other essential services and that threaten to slow recovery from the recession.

Susan Louise Agay, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Denes Agay of New York and Norton, Va., was married at noon yesterday to Charles Joseph Rothschild 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rothschild Jr. of Teaneck, N.J., Rabbi Louis Sigel performed the ceremony in the White and Gold Suite at the Plaza.
The stock market may be centering its long-awaited "correction" after the fabulous gains of recent months, but the consensus on Wall Street holds that any price pullback will be limited.
Nearly 200 Vietnamese refugees were flown from two United States relocation centers yesterday to new lives in Canada, according to The Associated Press.

Eight refugee children from Cyprus, dressed in colorful native attire, were wide-eyed but poised yesterday in a parade that brought 85,000 people onto Fifth Avenue to celebrate the 154th anniversary of Greek independence from Turkish invasion of Cyprus last year.

Never underestimate the power of Bronx politicians, Democratic or Republican. The boys have got together State Democratic and Bronx County chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, and Bronx County Republican chairman, Senator John D. Calandra and put a big one over in the New York State Senate. They would split off the Bronx from the First Judicial District, which it now shares with Manhattan, and create a separate district.

CHICAGO, May 18 (AP) Frank Robinson of the Cleveland Indians, major league baseball's first black manager, has been suspended for three days and fined $250 for an altercation with an umpire, Jerry Neudecker, in last night's 10-1 loss to the Chicago White Sox.
MOSCOW, May 18 (AP) A retired Red Army colonel in the Jewish emigration movement has been stripped of his rank and deprived of his officer's pension, Jewish sources reported today.

EUGENE, Ore., May 18 (AP) Australia's Chris Fisher handed Ben Jipcho a rare defeat in the mile at the International Track Association meet today, setting a professional record of 3 minutes 57.3 seconds.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 18 Saudi Arabia's Council of Ministers approved today a five-year economic plan of stupendous proportions calling for a $140-billion investment.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 18 (AP) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey says he came "close to quitting public life" as a result of illegal contributions to his campaigns by a dairy cooperative.

LOS ANGELES Mortgage bankers say that monthly payment delinquency rates on home mortgages are climbing in many parts of the country as a byproduct of the nation's worst recession in more than 25 years.

State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that Mayor Beame would have to commit the city to some ceiling on spending in the coming year to get state aid, but added that the ceiling amount would be negotiable and "part of the political process."
LOS ANGELES, May 18 Saying that she feels "marvelous," Betty Ford denied today reports that her husband would not seek a full term as President next year.

The Lancia touring team gained heavily against New York in the first of its four matches in this country at the New York Hilton Hotel Saturday night, and gave the large audience watching on VuGraph a dramatic evening's entertainment.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 18 A Sealyham, who has been on a tremendous winning streak during the last month, swept to her 19th top award today at the 73d Long Island Kennel Club Show. She was Mrs. Dorothy Wimer's Welsh import, Ch. Dersade Bobby's Girl from Churchtown, Pa., and she was handled by Peter Green.

The city's Environmental Protection Administration has approved construction of the long-planned Convention and Exhibition Center along the Hudson River in the West 40's, after sponsors of the controversial center agreed to prohibit public parking in its garage and to meet various other conditions.

The Platinum Information Bureau, which was recently established here to promote the sale of platinum in jewelry, has started a milliondollar magazine ad campaign to tell its story. Della Femina, Travisano Partners, Inc., the agency telling it, is going after two primary markets: brides and "empty nesters."

CAPE TOWN, May 18 South Africa has invited President Felix Houphouet Boigny of the Ivory Coast and President William R. Tolbert of Liberia to visit and government sources here are confident that they will accept.

WOODBURY, Conn., May 18 (UPI) Leroy Anderson, composer of popular music who wrote the wintertime standard "Sleigh Ride" during an August heat wave, as well as "Blue Tango," died today of lung cancer at his home. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 18 Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger announced today that the number of American casualties in last week's effort to rescue the freighter Mayaguez and her crew was larger than initially reported.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 18 (UPI) On the last deal of the "world series of poker" yesterday, Brian Roberts flipped over his hole cards both jacks and cleaned up $210,000.

"Tournament bridge is different in Europe than it is here," said Harold Ogust. "It's bridge the way it used to be a sport for the elite, played in casinos in dinner jackets. Here it's for the masses. More than 20 million people play regularly."
Ron Stewart, who played 21 seasons in the National Hockey League, is expected to be named coach of the New York Rangers today, replacing Emile Francis, who will remain as general manager.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 18 President Anwar el-Sadat, winding up a week-long tour of four Arab nations, declared here today that he had obtained a mandate to speak for the Arab world, not just Egypt, when he meets with President Ford in Salzbure, Austria, on June 1.

TAMPA, Fla., May 18 (AP) Sheriff's investigators and translators questioned today a Chinese seaman known locally as the "Wild Man of the Green Swamp," calming his fears and piecing together the story of his eight-month survival in the wilds of central Florida.

TIFFIN, Ohio, May 18 (UPI) Reporters who always look for scandal, mistakes and wrongdoing in every news event and Government official are doing a disservice to themselves and their readers, Ron Nessen, the White House press secretary, said here today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 18 (AP) The abrupt American evacuation from Saigon left behind about two dozen Americans, 150 South Koreans and 200 Pilipinos who wanted to flee on the airlift, according to figures of an international relief official.

Tens of thousands of black and Puerto Rican teen-agers in New York City, are "piling up at the bottom" of the recession. In the most ambitious oneday fund-raising effort for Jews, particularly in Israel and New York City, 8,000 volunteers yesterday dispersed through the greater metropolitan area on behalf of the United Jewish Appeal and the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.
WASHINGTON, May 18 The Shah of Iran said today that his Government was holding fewer than 3,000 persons in jail on charges related to "terrorist" actions.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, May 18 Senator Edward M. Kennedy will begin a four-day visit to Saudi Arabia Thursday at the start of a Middle East trip.

CLEVELAND, May 18 Gov. James A. Rhodes and 52 members of the state's National Guard go to trial tomorrow in what is expected to provide a new forum for the unraveling of the Kent State shootings of five years ago.

Vincent Lopez, who made his debut as leader of a dance band 59 years ago in the Pekin Restaurant at Broadway and 47th Street, is back on the bandstand again. Mr Lopez, who is 81, is leading a seven-piece band at the Riverboat, Fifth Avenue and 34th Street his first New York appearance since he wound up a 26-year engagement at the Taft Hotel nine years ago and moved to Miami.

In his news conference Friday, Mayor Beame insisted that the refusal of the Republicans to accept his tax-and-aid package would force the elimination of 38,000 additional jobs from the budget he must present this week, closing hospitals and schools, and reducing police, fire and sanitation services. The cuts were both a response to New York City's desperate financial situation and a theatrical gesture to create an uproar and to put pressure on Albany and Washington.
CINCINNATI, May 18 The General Assembly of the threemillion-member United Presbyterian Church has refused to recognize a homosexual caucus as an unofficial organization of the church.

HOLTSVILLE, L.I., May 18 The Suffolk County District Attorney's office disclosed today that it was investigating the payment of nearly $1-million in legal and rental fees to Brookhaven Republicans in connection with the construction of the huge Internal Revenue Service Center here.

Pay increases for New York City municipal workers in clerical office jobs, data processing, skilled trades and custodial services between April, 1973, and April, 1974, were below those in private industry here, a study made by the United States Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics showed yesterday.
Katie Sheldon Brennan, founder of the Brennan School of French Cuisine and a former government aide, died Saturday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital She was 35 years old and lived in Irvington, N.Y.

Kathe Schoenberg brought Some refreshingly offbeat programing to her Carnegie Recital Hall concert Saturday night. After a conventional start with songs by Purcell and Schumann, the mezzo-soprano turned to the gorgeous Opus 91 Brahms songs, with viola, then went on to a pair of thematically oriented groups Hungarian village airs arranged by Zoltan Kodaly and Laszlo Lajtha, and an engaging set of "almost lullabies" by Castelnuovo-Tedesco, Britten and Richard Strauss.

Bonnie Raitt made her annual pilgrimage to New York, appearing at Carnegie Hall on Saturday, her talents unimpaired and undiminished. She is a white woman who can latch onto a black blues song with ease and also use songs from such trendy contemporaries as Eric Andersen and Jackson Browne.

LANDOVER, Md., May 18 Badly outmuscled, out hustled and outshot in the first half, the Golden State Warriors stunned a crowd of 19,035 at Capital Centre today by rallying to beat the Washington Bullets, 101-95, in the opener of the National Basketball Association championship playoff.

OTTAWA, May 18 An American walked into a Canadian bank the other day and, presenting a $100 check on his New York bank to be cashed, was pleasantly surprised to get back $103 and change in Canadian money. It suggests a division into privileged and persecuted that is contrary to the fundamental definitions of our democracy.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The House, in the first post-Vietnam war test of its attitudes on defense policy, voted decisively today against reducing American troops overseas or making substantial cuts in the military budget.

The owners of an apartment cooperative that houses the Cafe Des Artistes at 1 West 67th Street obtained a temporary restraining order in State Supreme Court yesterday barring the cafe's owners from removing the murals painted by Howard Chandler Christy. The Vincent Astor Foundation has made a grant of $1million toward the restoration project of the South Street Seaport with the condition that the museum raise an additional $2.5-million for the $5-million project.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The House, in the first post-Vietnam war test of its attitudes on defense policy, voted decisively today against reducing American troops overseas or making substantial cuts in the military budget.

WASHINGTON, May 20 The Senate labor Committee, in the face of complaints from feminist and Hispanic groups that it was acting too hastily, approved today the nomination of Lowell W.
