WASHINGTON, May 21 The Senate Select Committee investigating Federal intelligence activities has sent the Justice Department a request for intelligence files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and documents that department officials say is unprecedented in scope.

WASHINGTON, May 21 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence was told today about domestic covert operation's by the Central Intelligence Agency that the panel's chairman, Senator Frank Church, later laid had "exceeded the law."

WASHINGTON, May 21-- J. Edgar Hoover, the late director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, feared that connections between the Central Intelligence Agency and the Chicago Mafia figure Sam Giancana would permit the racketeer to "blackmail the United States Government," according to former bureau officials.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 21 The first-round leader, Gary Head of Mountain Ridge, was victimized by four consecutive bogeys today, while Babe Lichardus of East Orange and Carlton White of Washington Valley shot under-par golf to create a three-way tie for the lead after two rounds of the Dodge open.

The Board of Education voted last night to renew the lease for the building occupied by Harlem Prep, despite objections from a board member who said the school should be moved into an empty city-owned school building in the community.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) Two Federal Service police officers, stopped a car on a routine traffic charge tonight and were shot and seriously wounded by one of its two oc- ... cupants, a spokesman for the service said.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 20 For about 350 Vietnamese refugee doctors, dentists and medical students who are awaiting security clearances to enter this country, the uncertainty of the future includes not fast where they will settle but when, if ever, they will practice in this country.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Mar 21 The State Power Authority announced today that it intended to build a 1.2-million-kilowatt nuclear power plant in Cementon, on the west bank of the Hudson River about four miles south of here, to supply electricity for New York City subways and commuter trains.

SCRANTON, Pa., May 21 (UPI) Former New Jersey State Treasurer Joseph M. Mc Crane Jr., convicted of conducting a scheme to get itlegal tax write-offs for Governor William T. Cahill's political contnbutors, was fined $20,000 and placed on three years' probation today.

John W. Rutledge has resigned as president of the Bulova Watch Company after little more than a year and a half on the job. The resigna tion was announced by Harry B. Henshel, chairman, who said Mr. Rutledge had resigned "to devote more time to several personal and business matters." Efforts to reach Mr. Rutledge for comment were unsuccessful.
State Education Commissioner, Ewald B. Nyquist said yesterday that it would be "unwise and illegal" for New York City to shorten its school week to save money.

ALBANY, May 21-- Governor Carey today presented the 1975 State Council on the Arts awards to 11 organizations and individuals and named Seymour H. Knox, who was chairman of the council For 15 years, as honorary chairman of the organization.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) A $6-billion economic emergency bill to extend and expand two temporary progrems of federally financed benefits for millions of jobless Americans was passed overwhelmingly by the House tonight.

PARIS, May 21 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing said today that the idea of an independent and unified European defense system could not usefully be discussed now, partly because of the "understandable Soviet fears of European military pressure."
ROME, May 21 Parliament tonight passed a controversial law aimed at curbing crime and political violence by broadening the powers of the police and of magistrates in pretrial proceedings.

The steel industry is embarking on an all-out drive seeking modification of pollution-control regulations. This became apparent in speeches at yesterday's opening sessions of the 83d annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Northeastern New Jersey lost 63,900 jobs, 61,400 of them in manufacturing, between March, 1974, and March, 1975, continuing a long-term decline in the ability of the area's economy to provide work for its residents.

UNIONDALE, L.I., May 21 The New York Sets have Billie Jean King, Virginia Wade, no defeats and no crowds. Tonight they returned to the Nassau Coliseum for their second home game and defeated the Los Angeles Strings, 28-26, before 2,345 fans.

Mayor Beame, backing off from his proposal of the days before, asserted yesterday that instituting a four-day work week for city employees as a way of cutting the deficit in the next budget would be poor financing.

The Forum of the Twelve Caesars, once one of the most opulent and dramatic restaurants in New York, may be on the verge of shutting down. Dining room personnel said yesterday that the restaurant, at 57 West 48th Street, in Rockefeller Center, would shut its doors on June 10. "The chef has already left," one captain said, "and everyone else is looking."

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI) The former head of LatinAmerican operations for the Central Intelligence Agency wrote the widow of President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile denying that the C.I.A. was in any way responsible for the Marxist leader's overthrow and death in 1973.

Anthony Davis, the Jets' top draft choice who wasn't even slated for full-time duty, has signed with the Southern California Sun of the World Football League for $300,000 cash as part of a 20-year, $2-million deal.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (AP) Three Soviet tankers have arrived at nearby Nha Be port with badly needed fuel for Saigon, where gasoline is selling for up to $8 a gallon. It was the first call at a South Vietnamese port by Soviet tankers.

BUFFALO, May 21 Defense and prosecution lawyers were repeatedly scolded today by a State Supreme Court justice for attempting to go "above and beyond" the issues relevant to the trial of an inmate leader of-the 1971 rebellion at Attica State Correctional Facility.
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., May 21-- Betty Ford visited former South Vietnamese Premier Nguyen Cao Ky today is what he called "my humble palace" is she toured the Southeast's Asian refugee center here.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va. May 21 (AP) Al Hamlin of Maryland won two events and finished second in two others today as he took a 134-point lead at the halfway mark of the I.C. 4-A decathlon championship.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., May 21 At an emotional and often raucous meeting here tonight the men and women of Fire Island told the National Park Service that its proposal to withdraw Federal supervision of their area was unacceptable.
Howard G. Sloane, managing director of the New York Col iseum, said yesterday that the Coliseum might be put out of business if the proposed West Side Convention Center was built.

FOUNTAIN VALLEY, Calif., May 21 (AP) Gladys Rousseau Karaskiewicz, the costume designer who revolutionized bathing suits for Mack Sennett's pioneer movie comedies, died today of a stomach cancer at Fountain Valley Community Hospital. She was 76 years old.

The Lambs Club, a Times Square landmark and long-time rendezvous for people in the theater, has been bought by a church that hopes to use it as a focal point from which to "clean up Times Square" according to the church's pastor.

Excavation for the Second Avenue subway has partially undermined the foundations of the colonnaded entrance to the Manhattan Bridge on Canal Street and three supporting columns of the Confucius Plaza housing complex under construction just to the south of the bridge in Chinatown, city officials said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 21 Administration officials said today that President Ford was virtually certain to announce a major energy-policy action before he leaves for Europe on May 28.
WASHINGTON, May 21 A renewed upturn in food prices in April produced the largest increase in three months in the Government's Consumer Price Index, the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 Administration spokesmen said today that 23 American servicemen killed in a helicopter crash in Thailand last week had embarked for possible use in the military operation to rescue the Mavauez and her crew.

News material from Associated Press correspondents in Saigon as received in New York shows no evidence of censorship-that is, of words, sentences or paragraphs deleted. But parts of articles sometimes fail to reach New York.

Three of the largest American store chains reported yesterday higher net profits in the first, fiscal quarter, reflecting a substantially stronger earnings trend over 1974 than among the major general merchandisecatalogue chains.
PARIS, May 21 New evideuce of the steepness of the economic decline in western industrialized countries was produced today by economists of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

The Justice Department yesterday called Dr. Sidney Fernbach, head of the computation department of the Lawrence Radiation Laboratories of the University of California at Livermore, as its first witness in its civil antitrust suit against the International Business Machines corporation.

It was Commissioner Gordon J. Davis who introduced the term "infrastructure" to last night's City Planning Commission hearing on a proposed special planning district for the South Richmond area of Staten Island.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 21 Three terrorists with submachine guns shot and killed two United States Air Force officers here early today.

The Firestone The and Rubber Company, the nation's second largest tire producer (after Goodyear), reported yesterday declines in net income of 8.4 per cent for the second fiscal quarter and 17.3 per cent for the six months ended April 30. Sales in these periods showed gains of 8 per cent and 6 per cent.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21 Another Middle East oil exporting country has called for increase in oil prices after the price freeze of the 13-nation organization of Petroleum Ex Exporting Countries expires Sept. 30.

Two taverns, as well as two neighbors who served a man liquor in their home the day his car struck and killed a woman while he was intoxicated, were named co-defendants yesterday in a $13-million damage suit.

WASHINGTON, May 21 Seventy-five Senators sent a letter to President Ford today saying that they expected the Administration to submit a foreign aid request to Congress that "will be responsive to Israel's urgent military and economic needs."

WASHINGTON, May 21 The Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives decided today to retreat and fight another day rather than face possible failure in attempting to override President Ford's veto of the strip mine control bill.

ALBANY, May 21 Want to buy the Brooklyn Bridge? Goodman, Manhattan Republican-Liberal.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 Dr. Wilbur W. Swingle, a biology professor at Princeton University for 30 years, died yesterday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 84 years old.

CINCINNATI, May 21 More than 700 representatives of the nation's 2.8 million United Presbyterians ended their eightday General Assembly here this afternoon after committing their church to the proposition that religion must play a significant role in this country's bicentennial. Scali, the former television newsman, who has served since February, 1973. The nomination requires Senate approval.

The W.T. Grant Company, which suffered a $177.3-million loss in its last fiscal year, widened its deficit for the first quarter to $53.9-million from the $12.3-million loss in the first 1974 quarter, shareholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting.
EDGEWATER, N.J. Living along the edge of the Hudson River at the bottom of a sharp cliff poses certain physical and psychological perils.

HARTFORD, May 21 The Connecticut General Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill requiring that the meetings, records and official correspondence of all state and local governmental agencies be open to the public.

Yesterday Fairfax Cone, One of the grand old men of the advertising business, severed his last tie with the advertising agency he ran for so many years. He did not stand for re-election to the board of Foote, Cone Belding, from which he retired in 1970. He is 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) The Commerce Department said today that at least 49 American exporters had violated trade laws by failing to disclose they had been asked to participate in the Arab trade boycott of Israel.

Speculators seeking refuge in commodities as a hedge against the declining value of the dollar actively bought silver futures yesterday. Trading was described as "hectic" on the Commodity Exchange, where 15,653 contracts changed hands, one of silver's busiest days.

Financial reports of New York State nursing homes for 1974 disclose that their costs were far lower than the estimates on which their Medicaid reimbursement rates had been based. As a result, they obtained a windfall profit that may come to $70-million, and little of it would appear to be recoverable immediately.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The White House said today that the United States was committed to the "survival of a free and independent Israel," but it declined to respond directly to the urging of 76 Senators that President Ford recommend enough military and economic aid to meet Israel's urgent needs.

Viola Farber did not so much give a tight laced, formal dance concert, around the McGrawHill building on Sixth Avenue, as assert a dance presence and a right to occupy the space. The early evening performance Wednesday was done with so much spirit and good humor that her dancers drew the audience behind them like the children of Hamlin to see the conclusion half a block away from the starting site.
Nine students at Queens College have shaped a dream into a "syndicate" and have bought a 30 per cent interest in a racehorse that is scheduled to run under their colors at Aqueduct next Wednesday.

NEWARK, May 22 (UPI) The Newark Housing Authority has voted unanimously to repossess an urban renewal site given to the Temple of Kawaida for a housing complex. It cited as its reason "the organization's inability to secure a city tax abatement necessary for undertaking the project."

WASHINGTON, May 22 American Airlines has agreed to pay a Civil penalty of $150,000 as a partial settlement of a case in which it was accused of disbursing nearly twice that amount in illegal political contributions, The Washington Post reported in its Friday editions.

MEMPHIS, May 22 (AP) John Mahaffey's string of eight birdies in 10 holes produced a 65 today that tied him with Tom Weiskopf and Andy North for the firstround lead in the $175,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis open golf tournament.
LISBON, May 22 The Socialist party, concerned over what it fears is the erosion of its freedom and power, today made its most open challenge to the Armed Forces Movement that rules Portugal.
With the determination of Stanley after Livingston, a family of five decided that on successive weekends it would see four "jungle safaris" and game farms that surround the city.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it would postpone indefinitely a proposed regulation that would permit federally chartered savings and loans associations to offer variable rate mortgages.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 22 The United States, at the request of the Laotian Government, has agreed to end all activities of the Agency for International Development in Laos outside of Vientiane and to negotiate for the complete termination of the agency's programs.

Pension applications by 194 policemen and firemen or their widows were stalled yesterday when union representatives boycotted two meetings in a dispute with the city over its interpretation of the retirement law.

Steve Reich is now giving four identical concerts of his works at the Kitchen (Wooster and Broome Streets), and the key piece is the last, entitled "Work in Progress for 21 musicians and singers." (The final two are tonight and tomorrow night at 9 o'clock.)

WASHINGTON, May 22 The National Association of Broadcasters told the Senate Antitrust Subcommittee today that it opposed the offering of Television programs for a fee over cable only because the system might force the American people to pay for events it now sees on "conventional, or free, television."

The Lancia touring team, including several Italian world champions, is finding the American opposition tougher than expected. A $184-million deficit reported yesterday by the trustees of the Penn Central Railroad for the first four months of this year brought to $1.4-billion the aggregate net loss incurred by the huge system since it filed for bankruptcy reorganization in June, 1970. The net loss for April alone was $56-million.

BALTIMORE, May 22 (UPI) Three jockeys who were disqualified from riding at Pimlico after their indictment on race-fixing charges filed a motion today for reinstatement pending a Maryland Racing Commission hearing next week.

WASHINGTON, May 22 L. Dean Brown, director of the Administrator's interagency task force on Indochina refugees, said today that about 1,000 Vietnamese who left their country in the last month now wanted to return to South Viet nam.

WASHINGTON, May 22 The Internal Revenue Service announced today that tax-exempt status would be denied henceforthth to church-affilated primary and secondary schools that refuse to accept children from all racial and ethnic groups.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, May 23 (UPI) Cambodian Communist troops have captured a cliff along the Thai border, overrunning a small force of Anti-Communist soldiers holding out since the collapse of the Phnom Penh Government last month, Thai officials said today.
SHANGHAI, May 22 (AP) A slip of a girl named Li Shin threw the javelin 189 feet 4 inches today and gave the Americans their first surprise in their track and field tour of China.

Former Representative John H. Ray, who was first elected to Congress from Staten Island and part of Brooklyn in 1952 after retiring at 65 as vice president and general counsel of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Wednesday at his home. WASHINGTON, May 22 Dr. George W.F. Hallgarten, a historian, died today of a heart attack in Sibley Hospital here. He was 74 years old.
Several thousand people last night attended a concert of the American Symphony Orchestra playing a salute to American music at Sheep Meadow in Central Park.

The Apawamis Country Club, representing Westchestes, won the intersectional playoffs of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at the Sunningdale Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. Apawamis defeated Piping Rock of Long Island and Somerset Hills of New Jersey. Apawamis won, by half a point with 16 points to 16 for Piping Rock and 12 for Somerset Hills. The victory was the seventh for Apawamis since 1952.

"The Wind and the Lion," which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, is an elaborate, expensive-looking, ludicrously jingoistic historical-adventure that comes out so firmly in favor of Teddy Roosevelt's "Big Stick" policy, 70 years later, that it could also be a put-on.
DENVILLE, N.J., May 22 Billy Ziobro is so far down the golf tour money-winning list that the Internal Revenue Service could miss his name. But he is rich in automobiles.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22 The United Nations aid program for Palestinian refugees is facing the worst financial crisis in its quarter-century of activity and may have to cut back soon on essential services, officials here said today.

ALBANY, May 22 Testiness marked debates in the two houses of the Legislature today as the Senate engaged in controversy over a salute to the Marine Corps's handling of the Mayaguez incident, and an Assemblyman charged that his bill had been plagiarized.

BOSTON, May 21 In April, 1974, Boston police recorded 14 crimes involving the use of firearms in which no firearm was captured. In 114 other gun crimes, a firearm handgun, rifle or shotgun was taken by the police. In April of this year, 18 crimes involving firearms, but in which none was taken, and 59 in which a firearm was captured, were recorded by the police.

Financial reports of New York State nursing homes for 1974 disclose that their costs were far lower than the estimates on which their Medicaid reimbursement rates had been based. As a result, they obtained a windfall profit that may come to $70-million, and little of it would appear to be recoverable immediately.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 22 (AP) Gen. Oswaldo Lopez Arellano, in his first public appearance since he was overthrown as the Honduran chief of state last month, said that neither he nor former Economy Minister Abraham Bennaton Ramos were implicated in a banana bribe scandal.

CONCORD, N.H., May 22 (UPI) The New Hampshire Senate gave final legislative approval today, 18 to 5, to a bill permitting school districts to allow prayer in the schools and recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance.

Leaders of the city's financial community laid down conditions last night for lending the city $280-million to ease its current financial crisis. They did so in a letter to Controller Harrison J. Goldin, who said he considered it "tantamount to a rejection" of the city's request for a loan in that it "may constitute requirements that cannot be met."
DETROIT, May 22 The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation have recalled another 5,900 workers even though over-all United States car production was off this week.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 22 Even after his 3minute-53.3-second mile and surgery this week for an infected tooth, Eamonn Coghlan has lost none of his enthusiasm for tomorrow's 99th annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America outdoor track and field championships.

ALBANY, May 22 Governor Carey today banned outside employment for members of his administration who earn $30,000 a year or more or who hold "policymaking positions," and he ordered the same employes to make detailed annual disclosures of their net worth and sources of income.

Bob R. Dorsey, chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, said yesterday that he did not intend to go to Bolivia to reply to a summons calling for his appearance with regard to illegal political contributions in that country.
WASHINGTON, May 22 Representative Robert L.F. Sikes told the House of Representatives today that The New York Times had accused him of a conflict of interest, and he said this was untrue.
MOSCOW, May 22 Aleksandr N. Shelepin, who was removed from the ruling Politburo last month, lost his job as head of the national trade union organization today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 Three more reports by the United States Civil Service Commission citing Failure by Government agencies in personnel management and inadequate compliance with equal employment opportunity regulations were made available here yesterday.

One of the nice things about the New York Philharmonic Promenades is that they resurrect pieces that were once popular in symphonic programs but are no longer played. Lalo's Overture to "Le Roi d'Ys," for example, is a beautifully crafted, lovely work that in another day any conductor worth his salt would have been glad to put on a program. It is ignored now as being too lightweight, as though only masterpieces were allowed.

Directors of the United States Railway Association said yesterday that they had ordered studies of three possible plans as a means of restructuring and reorganizing the Northeast's seven major bankrupt railroads. The studies are to be completed before directors' next meeting, May 29.

BUFFALO, May 22 A prosecution witness today identified Bernard Stroble as one of the inmates who escorted two fellow inmates from a prison yard during the 1971 Attica uprising. The two inmates were found dead of multiple stab wounds after the rebellion was quelled.

WASHINGTON, May, 22 A few weeks ago, as South Vietnam was on the verge of collapse, Secretary of State Kissinger found time for a leisurely two-hour chat with a Representative he scarcely knew.

He is a free agent, although the Jets want him back and hope to reopen negotiations soon with Jimmy Walsh, Namath's attorney.

How a typical Broadway musical comes into being, as described by Michael Bennett: "The director sits in a room with the composer and lyricist for a year. The costumes and sets are designed. Orchestrations are done." And then, finally, actors begin rehearsing, with the hours strictly limited.

WASHINGTON, May 22-Congress left today for a 10day Memorial Day recess after postponing until next month legislation that would finance a $50 cash payment to every recipient of Social Security benefits.

Bill Bradley, the National Basketball Association's Rhodes Scholar, may soon be joined by another of his kind, 23-year-old Tom McMillen. He resisted the lure of the professional sports dollar in the United States this season to attend Oxford University after-graduating from the University of Maryland in 1974.

For a number of conservative candidates he is already the indispensable man with the indispensable mailing lists. As such he may have as much control as any individual over the emergence of a new political party in the Presidential election of 1976.

Bertram A. Powers has been re-elected president of Typographical Union No. 6 for his eighth two-year term, according to an election tally completed yesterday.

An ophthalmologist in a survey of 156 students in Wales, has found the corneas of those with blue eyes are the most sensitive to touch, and those with dark brown eyes are the least sensitive.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22 Jim Bradley, a reserve, stood on a locker smoking a big cigar. Artis Gilmore's Afro hairdo was filled with confetti and his body was covered with champagne that his Kentucky Colonel teammates had poured over his huge 7-foot-2-inch frame.

Robert Moses (Lefty) Grove, a member of Baseball's Hall of Fame who as a star pitcher with Connie Mack's Philadelphia Athletics in the nineteen-twenties and thirties won 300 major-league games, died last night, apparently of a heart attack, in Norwalk, Ohio. He was 75 years old.
PARIS, May 22 Fresh turbulence struck European financial markets today' as the dollar was battered anew and the price of gold rose sharply.
Research on fetuses has enabled doctors to prevent an abortion in a case where it was feared the unborn child was a victim of a debilitating hereditary blood disease known as Cooley's anemia.

An amateur advertising enthusiast recently expressed surprise that despite special Food and Drug Administration interest and a possible ingredient ban the manufacturers of Sure, Secret and Arrid Double X antiperspirants don't appear to have pulled back on their advertising in any way. "You'd think they'd be trying for a low profile," he said.

A jury found yesterday in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York that the New York Stock Exchange was not liable for $2.2million in damages sought by the family of James McDonnell, founder of McDonnell Co., an exchange member firm that collapsed in 1970.

The New York Stock Exchange yesterday reported that in the month ended May 15 the short interest position rose by 748,873 shares to a record total of 26,709,752. This is the second consecutive month for a record total.

The stock market moved in a narrow range yesterday in slower trading and finished with small gains. Analysts noted that the market was in a consolidation phase following its sharp advance of this year.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 21 (Reuters) A land, air and water search was under way today in the Lake Tanganyika region for three Stanford University students and a Dutch woman who were abducted from a wildlife research station on Monday by 40 armed men.

A $500 personal check from President Ford for the White House swimming-pool fund, with a note saying that it was a joint contribution from him and his wife, Betty, was received yesterday by William Schuiling, secretarytreasurer of the pool committee. Like other contributions to the fund, it is tax-deductible. Lee Currlin, an executive, in the CBS-TV sales department, yesterday was appointed vice president in charge of programs for the network. He succeeds Fred Silverman, who last week was hired away from CBS by ABC-TV.
DETROIT, May 23 Auto producers reported today that sales of domestic new cars for mid-May fell 27.7 per cent below 1974 to a 14-year low.

Francis Curtis Thayer, president of United States Productions, Inc., a producer of documentary films for business, industrial and general distribution, died yesterday after surgery in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived at 47 East 88th Street.

WHITE PLAINS, May 23 (AP) ?Moms Mabley, the rubberfaced comedienne with the toothless grin and baggy clothing, dead here tonight after a long illness. She was 77 years old.

DETROIT, May 23 Despite dismal auto sales so far this year, Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, maintained his optimistic view today at the company's annual meeting and predicted that 1975 would be a "turnaround year for our economy and our business."

LISBON, May 23 Portugal's military rulers met separately today with leaders of the Socialist and Communist parties in what may be a last effort to maintain civilian political participation in the Government.

ONSTED, Mich., May 23 (UPI) The police dug today for more bodies in the yard of a rural home once occupied by a former mental patient wanted for questioning in the killings of 20 persons in California, Michigan, Texas and Washington State.
ATLANTA, May 23 It still bothers Jon Matlack that he hasn't pitched a complete game this season, but the Mets' left-hander wasn't complaining about his 3-1 victory tonight over the Braves.
The State Charter Revision Commission for New York City was told yesterday that its sweeping recommendations for overhauling a "sluggish, overcertralized municipal bureaucracy did not so far enough.
The stock market, spurred by a cut in the prime interest rate by the First National City Bank, posted a broad advance yesterday in continued active trading.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 23 A former Suffolk County legislator whose recommendations led to the approval of a proposed $20-million quarter-horse race track in the county was indicted here today on charges of soliciting and receiving a bribe from a consulting company that eventually received a contract from the track.

WASHINGTON, May 23 Responding to criticism by Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Federal Energy Administration has decided to revise its formula for phasing out crude oil price controls over two years, an official said today.
WASHINGTON, May 23 President Ford said today that he would ask the leaders of the Atlantic alliance next week to consider whether Portugal's leftist Government should remain a member.

Governor Carey met privately for several hours yesterday with his four emergency advisers on New York City's twin fiscal crises and said afterward that he thought "things are working in the right direction."

ROSELLE, N.J., May 23 Ch. Westfield Cunomorus Stone, the greatest winning bulldog bitch in the history of the breed, took her 22d best-in-show award today at the Union County Kennel Club's first spring show. There were 1,096 dogs in the competition at the Warinanco Park skating rink.

"Most people don't take advantage of the space they have," Noel Jeffrey, an interior designer, said the other evening as he and his wife, Lynn, waited for dinner guests. "In-Manhattan there just isn't space to waste."

Leaders of some of the unions representing city employes now appear to feel that sizable layoffs may be inevitable in the current fiscal crisis, but they are holding firm to their deter mination not to make further concessions that would erode their contracts.

BRUSSELS, May 23 Stressing the continued danger of growing Soviet military strength despite the encouragement of detente, the defense ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today on the basis for long-term alliance plans.

The Schlumberger Electric Company, a subsidiary of Schlumberger, Ltd., disclosed late Thursday it had been advised that approximately 2,233,000 common shares, or about 84 per cent of the common shares.
The first Mormon missionary to New York City, Elder Parley P. Pratt, wrote dolefully of his meagre success at winning converts during the first few months of his efforts in 1837.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 23 (Reuters) Trailand wants diplomatic relations with North Vietnam as soon as possible, Premier Kukrit Pramoj said today on the second day of talks here between the the countries.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission refused today to approve in principle the Kennecott Corporation's attempt to sell the Peabody Coal Company to one of three bidders.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, May 23 The International Olympic Committee has got nowhere by listening to the "two China" problem and has decided to solve the issue by taking a look for itself.

Eleo Pomare's dances always have a special gutsy quality. Part of this impression stems from the fact that Mr. Pomare, like several other black choreographers, is keeping the fading but necessary tradition of social protest alive.
TEL AVIV, May 23 Michael Tzur, until recently a major power in Israel's economy, was sentenced here today to 15 years in prison.

A growing number of physicians, especially on Long Island, are threatening to curtail their practices beginning June 1 in opposition to the state's new malpractice law, which they say still leaves doctors uninsurable.
After two major demonstrations at City Hall over alleged police brutality in Chinatown, the commanding officer of the Chinatown precinct was relieved of his post yesterday.
The nearest thing to a sureshot victory in major league baseball this season seems to be Nolan Ryan, the California Angels' right-hander who uses his pitching arm like a flame-thrower.

HARTFORD, May 23 Gov. Ella T. Grasso agreed today, subject to the approval of the General Assembly, to pay Connecticut's state employes the raises they were to have been denied in the coming fiscal year, by diverting $5.3-million that the state had earmarked for the State Employes Retirement Fund.

CLEVELAND Steve Menyhart, an American citizen and confirmed suburbanite, used to be Istvan Menyhart, a Hungarian rebel. He remembers well what it was like in the beginning of his new life in the United States after he fled his homeland in 1956, when Soviet troops crushed the Hungarian revolt. Unable to speak English and largely helpless at that time, Mr. Meynhart says today, "You felt like a baby who don't know nothing."

Irma Ellis wanted her 8year-old son, Emery, to study art after school. He wanted instead to learn magic tricks. And so he enrolled in the magic class at the Walden School Community Program, where he also takes karate and where he learned woodworking.
Elizabeth Walker Valentine and Robert MacPherson Gardiner, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Reynolds Securities, Inc., were married in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday afternoon.

The State Health Department yesterday pledged to recover, huge windfall profits just disclosed in records filed by nursing homes and to plug the loopholes in the Medicaid system that had made them possible.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The Council on Wage and Price Stability recommended today that the Federal Government finance a program to install airbags in 100,000 small cars for field testing before American automobile manufacturers are required to make them standard equipment.

TRENTON, May 23 (AP) Governor Byrne, in a warning to all department heads and directors of state authorities, charged today that a memo issued by John P. Gallagher, executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, had "the potential of obstructing" a state grand jury investigation into contracts for Garden State Parkway supplies and equipment. He cautioned others to avoid making a similar mistake.

Thousands of travelers took to the highways and jammed airports and train and bus ter minals yesterday to get an early start on the three-day Memorial Day weekend that traditionally opens the summer season.
DEVON, Pa., May 23 (AP) Kathy Anker of Readington, N.J., rode Test Pattern to a class victory in the large junior working hunter event today at the start of the Devon Horse Show.

Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative of New York, has called upon the Federal Communications Commission and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting to investigate WNET's payment of $2,500 to Abbie Hoffman, a fugitive charged with selling cocaine, for a television interview.

The repertory for woodwind quintet is not short of works that are challenging to the players, but it is by no means awash in masterpieces of the sort that make engrossing listening. So the Boehm Quintette has been busy in recent seasons commissioning works by composers whom the group believes will make a "serious contribution to the literature," in the words of a program note for its concert at Alice Tully Hall an Thursday night.
MOSCOW, May 23 (Reuters) Diplomatic observers in Moscow expressed skepticism today over a report that the Soviet Union had concluded a large arms pact to provide Libya with weapons worth $4billion.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Treasury Department today proposed legislation that would permit the Federal Government to earn interest on the billions of dollars of its deposits which sit idly in bank accounts every year.
READING, Mass., May 23 (AP) Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti stopped the loan of surveillance equipment today to local police departments until tighter controls on their use were worked out.

Betty Jones and Fritz Ludin were pioneers in touring as a duet with repertory pieces by a variety of able choreographers. An if their programs have been a shade more exciting at other times, their appearance at Pace College's Schimmel Center on Thursday evening had is special pleasures.
There were fewer mechanical problems yesterday and an increase in betting volume as New Jersey's new numbers-like lottery game moved into its second day of operation.
Last July Citicorp, the holding company that controls the First National City Bank, introduced a fascinating investment concept floating-rate notes.

PARIS, May 23 (AP) The last peace negotiator for the Provisional Revolutionary Government in South Vietnam left Paris today, closing the last chapter in seven years of talks on ending the Vietnam war.
The National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday that new orders for electrical equipment increased by 8 per cent in March over the February level.

GENEVA, May 23-Hermann Mayer, an Austrian business man accused by the United States's Securities and Exchange Commission of concealing substantial holdings in the General Refractories Company, said today he was certain he could "defend myself very well."

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 23 Laos's Premier said today that, in an effort to prevent a new civil war here, he had ordered right-wing Government troops not to resist when Pathet Lao forces moved into their territory.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose sharply yesterday while volume remained the same. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.
CHICAGO, May 23 After the cocktails were ingested last night in a decidedly unVictorian manner, the 75 guests checked the ornate calligraphy of their place cards.
Heavy marketings of wheat, corn and soybeans by farmers helped to depress prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Ellen Stock, a senior editor with New York magazine, and Peter Stern, production manager of the Broadway musical "Goodtime Charley," were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Norton Shargel of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Harris.

The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it would lower its prime rate on corporate loans to 7 per cent on Monday. The move reflected continued weak demand for loans and lower interest rates on competing sources of borrowed funds.

WASHINGTON, May 23 Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that, in the period from 1960 to 1971, the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted five previously undisclosed counterintelligence programs against domestic political organizations, including one designed to turn organized crime elements against the American Communist party.

Fifty years ago radios flickered and sputtered in very few parlors across the land. Broadcasting was then a four-year-old reality and its programs reached listen ers gathered around a rudimentary two-part apparatus that consisted of a receiver a bunch of tubes sprouting from a mahogany slab base and a speaker a pedistal-based, wheel-shaped metal device with a grill cloth instead of a hubcap, centering one side.

DEMAREST, N.J. May 22 Just 14 miles from the hubbub of New York City lies this idyllic community where the ducks once had their own bank account and where couples still pose for pictures under "the wedding tree" alongside Tenakill Brook.

TRENTON, May 23 The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered a redistribution of $300-million in state school aid next year unless the Legislature complied with its mandate and approved a new system of financing public schools. The ruling was by a 4-to-2 vote of the justices.
Rudolf F. Benesh, a choreographer, died in London on May 3, according to the American Institute of Choreology, who reported his death in this country. He was 59 years old and lived in London.

The circle of people whose actions and decisions will most immediately determine whether New York continues to slide toward defeault has shrunk to three, and they will be meeting for breakfast Tuesday morning. They are Mayor Beame, Governor Carey and Warren M. Anderson, the Re publican majority leader of the State Senate. Mayor Beame will...
The ability of the Italian superstars to produce a storming finish when it is most needed seems suddenly to have deserted them.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) The former South Vietnamese Vice Premier, Nguyer Cao Ky sporting a United States flag pin in his lapel, was reunited with his family tonight for the first time since the fall of the Thieu regime in Saigon.

NEWARK, May 23 Governor Byrne was barred today by an informal but binding order by a state superior court judge from taking any further action to unseat Ralph DeRose as New Jersey member of the bistate Waterfront Commission until the court has ruled on the merits of the Governor's case next month.
Pro basketball news erupted in the legal courts and on the trading fronts yesterday and involved some of the sport's biggest names:

MEMPHIS, May 23 (AP) John Mahaffey birdied two of the last three holes today for a four-under-par 68 and pulled away to a two-stroke lead after the second round of the $175,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis open.
CHICAGO, May 23 Disclosures of widespread corruption and bribery in the handling of grain exports at the port of New Orleans came as no surprise to the grain trade.

Robert C. Eunson, a longtime foreign correspondent and The Associated Press executive who was vice president in charge of broadcast activities for the last 10 years, died Thursday of cancer. He was 62 years old and lived at 1520 York Avenue.
MADRID, May 23(U.P.I.) The Spanish Government imposed a news blackout today on two Basque provinces where the authorities are trying to stamp out anti-Government agitation and terrorism.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) With little ceremony and no fanfare, the Vietnam Embassy has closed its doors, leaving its 40 employes sad, jobless and with an uncertain future.

Two points remained, clear about the Organization of American States after the close of its annual General Assembly: the 24 member governments want the organization to survive; most of them want its headquarters to stay in Washington. No action was taken on the statement by Assistant Secretary of State William D. Rogers that the United States would be willing to transfer the O.A.S. to another country if a majority of members so desired.
WASHINGTON, May 22 Representative Richard L. Ottinger, in a rare move, has urged the Social Security Administration to stop sending checks to one of his con stituents.

ROME, May 23-A chief state prosecutor here opened a judicial inquiry this week into allegations that the United Brands Company had been bribing Italian Government officials for years to obtain favored treatment for its banana exports to Italy.
A Queens police sergeant, suspended since his indictment along with nine fellow members of an alleged "sergeants club" at the 103d Precinct in Jamaica, was found guilty on a perjury charge yesterday.
The first Mormon missionary to New York City, Elder Parley P. Pratt, wrote dolefully of his meagre success at winning converts during the first few months of his efforts in 1837.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. The Class of 1975 on the nation's campuses is marching out into an indifferent world. Its members face the worst recession since the 1930's, and, to a greater extent than most people realize the burdens of recession fall heavily on the young.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (AP) A three-judge Federal court has ruled that a church seeking to hold services for homosexual prison inmates is a bonafide church and must be guaranteed freedom of religion.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) In a policy shift, the Justice Department decided today to review its defense of the new Federal election law after a top official questioned the law's constitutionality.

As soon as it became evident that Catfish Hunter was en route to his sixth victory in his last seven starts, this time by 11-7, Beanball War II erupted between the Yankees and the Texas Rangers at Shea Stadium last night.

MANILA, May 23 President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the United States and the Philippines must build a new relationship based on a realistic view of whether there is a need for either the American instalations here or the mutual defense treaty.

Worried about the city's budget crisis and layoffs? Does the talk of payless days or a four-day week get you down? A note tucked in with paychecks distributed to city employes yesterday reminded them the Health Department's special counseling unit was there to help them with their troubles.

BRUSSELS, May 23 (UPI) The dollar fell today to its lowest mark against the French franc in more than 22 months. On other European money markets trading in the dollar was mixed. The price of gold fell.

THE HAGUE, Saturday, May 24 The Netherlands Cabinet decided conditionally late last night to buy the American F-16 jet fighter instead of the competing French-made Mirage to replace its squadrons of F-104 Starfighters. But the purchase will be made only on the stipulation that Denmark, Norway and Belgium, which have formed a consortium with the Netherlands for the purchase, also buy the same aircraft.

Also shown are closing listed market prices of best over-the-Counter dollar-to-dollar asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference (discount on premium) between the net asset value and the asked prices of the capital shares.

HARTFORD, May 23 Gov. Ella T. Grasso agreed today, subject to the approval of the General Assembly, to pay Connecticut's state employes the raises they were to have been denied in the coming fiscal year, by diverting $5.3-million that the state had earmarked for the State Employee Retirement Fund.
After two major demonstrations at City Hall over alleged police brutality in Chinatown, the commanding officer of the Chinatown precinct was relieved of his post yesterday.

It's fun to see a pop performer arrive on the scene already a star, and that's what Ernmylou Harris did Thursday night at the Bottom Line. She appeared there only one night, but she will be back for the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park on June 28.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Government's inflation monitoring agency said today that speculation was not a significant factor in last year's soaring sugar prices.

ALBANY, May 23 State Controller Arthur Levitt charged today that a state agency created in 1968 primarily to channel Rockefeller family contributions into state conservation work had made a number of questionable expenditures during the three and a half years that Henry L. Diamond, a confidant of former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, served as the agency's chairman.
ALBANY, May 23 Speaker Stanley Steingut today dropped 681 employes from the Assembly payroll, citing as a cause for cost-cutting the uncertainty over when the legislative session would end.
WASHINGTON, May 23 President Ford said today that he would ask the leaders of the Atlantic alliance next week to consider whether Portugal's leftist Government should remain a member.
COLOGNE, West Germany Superb cuisine, contrary to a cherished American belief, is highly appreciated in Germany. Sometimes it can even be found here.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (UPI) The Army has announced that a Reserve general commanding 9,000 reservists in three states was relieved of duty on charges of improper conduct involving misuse of authority and funds.

TORREJON AIR BASE, Spain, May 23 (UPI) Secretary of State Kissinger stopped here today, on his way back to Washington, for talks with Foreign Minister Pedro Cortina Mauri of Spain on such matters as Portugal's swing toward the left.

MERTHYR TYDFIL, Wales, May 22 Richard Mackey, the principal of a Roman Catholic school, and William Morgan, a minister of the Church in Wales, are close friends who have worked in the same vineyards of the Labor party for years, backing the same candidates and the same causes.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today new standards to protect the public from radiation released by nuclear reactors and by the processing of uranium used to power reactors.

MADRID, May 23 (AP) The Spanish Government, pressured by Arab neighbors and fearful of a guerrilla war, announced today that it was ready to give independence to the Spanish Sahara "in the shortest period possible."

Castle Clinton, the weathered, darkbrown bagel of a building set in the salad greenery of Battery Park on Manhattan's harborside tip, opens its doors to the public this afternoon for the first time in more than 35 years.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) The Senate rejected a subpoena yesterday for confidential financial records of former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, who is now on trial on bribery, perjury and conspiracy charges.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 23-A fleet of 124 yachts? or was it 125??ranging in size from the 80-foot ketch Tempest down to a trio of 26 foot Midget Ocean Racing Division sloops, set sail this evening in the Storm Trysail Club's 30th annual race to Block Island and back. Unless the wind pipes up the voyage for around 700 yachtsmen is going to consume most of this holiday weekend.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 23 A spokesman for Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, today disputed assertions made in Washington that Vietnamese refugees wishing to return home were being impeded from doing so.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, May 23 (Reuters) Tanzanian policemen and troops combing the eastern shore of Lake Tanganyika have found no trace of four kidnapped American and Dutch students and are certain they are being held in Zaire.

WASHINGTON, May 23 A South Vietnamese ship that arrived at Guam last week with 522 refugees also reportedly carried crates of what may be part of that country's art treasures. But officials here maintain that they do not know the contents of the crates or who owns them.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 Counted out two weeks ago, the Golden State Warriors took a stranglehold on the National Basketball Association championship tonight by beating the Washington Bullets, 109-101, for a 3-0 lead in the four-of-sevengame series.

LONDON, May 23 (Reuters) Pan American World Airways today won a legal battle involving commission rates against the British Government, which had threatened to suspend Pan Am permits to fly into Britain.

Pots were being boiled all over Lincoln Center on Thursday night as New York City Ballet went into Phase Two of its current Ravel Festival at the New York State Theater. In a furious spate of creativity the company presented its faithful audience with five new ballets in one evening. Unfortunately each one of them was a clinker. One would have felt like saying back to the drawing board in hte first place.
WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) Richard Thornburgh, United States Attorney for western Pennsylvania, will be nominated as assistant Attorney General for the Criminal Division, President Ford said yesterday.
A filly will rave against a dozen colts in the 100th running of the Withers Stakes at Aqueduct today. William Haggin Perry's Sarsar will undertake the task in the one-mile test for 3-year.

HONG KONG, May 23 (AP) Several supporters of the former South Vietnamese Government were killed by villagers after they failed to surrender their weapons and to register with the new Government, the Saigon radio said today.

In an unusual concession to its merchandise creditors, the W.T. Grant Company is offering 1,500 of its largest suppliers a lien on its inventory and prior claim for repayment over its principal lending banks should Grant become bankrupt.

A few hundred rounds of golf were played on Van Cortlandt Park Golf Club in the Bronx in 1889, the year the nine-holer was opened as the first public links course in the nation. It was run then as now by New York City.

RIYADH, May 23 King Khalid of Saudi Arabia has told Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who is visiting here, that the Arab countries cannot relieve energy problems for the United States until there is a "just" solution to the Middle East conflict with Israel.
MIAMI, May 20 Some of the 350,000 Cuban exiles who have resettled here so successfully over the last 16 years are collecting food and clothing for the Vietnamese refugees now headed this way.
Melissa Carr Leib and Robert Illingworth Veghte were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Charles Newberry at St. John's Episcopal Church of Lattingtown in Locust Valley, L.I.

HONK KONG, May 23 (AP) The Mayaguez arrived in Hong Kong tonight and her owners opened six sealed cargo containers at the request of newsmen seeking to learn if a vessel was carrying military equipment when it was seized by a Cambodian patrol boat last week.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The Central Intelligence Agency prepared "contingency" plans for the assassination of Cuban Premier Fidel Castro as a result of White House discussions, former agency officials have told the Rockefeller Commission, which is looking into Federal intelligence operations.

Levi said today that, in the period from 1960 to 1971, the Federal Bureau of Investigation conducted five previously undisclosed counterintelligence programs against domestic political organizations, including one designed to turn organized crime elements against the American Communist party.

On the eve of the Memorial Day weekend, the State's Department of Parks and Recreation has imposed sharp cuts in state park facilities open to the public, including some areas of Jones Beach and Bear Mountain.

PARIS From July, 1789, to May, 1968, France was the theatrical showcase for previewing the major trends of modern history at first, through the liberal revolution against the privileges and injustices of the Old Regime; in our own day, through, rebellion against the many-layered and anonymous dictatorship of the profit motive and by movement toward socialist democracy.

The city's new fire safety code for high-rise office buildings, the most stringent such law in the nation, is beset as few other local laws have been by debate over its technical and economic feasibility.

The Chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Lydia St. John Geer, daughter of Mrs. Howard Earl Geer of Meadow Lakes Village, N.J., formerly of New York, and the late Mr. Geer, to Dr. Charles Ellison Hillyer of Cliffside Park, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John K. Hammon.

Joseph Papp is planning to take over the Booth Theater on Broadway next season to present five new American plays. Discussions have been held between Mr. Papp, producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival, and representatives of the Shubert organization, owners of the Booth and most other Broadway theaters.

In "American Building and the Forces That Shaped It," Prof. James Marston Fitch of Columbia wrote that "the 19th century saw three great developments in structural theory: the enclosure of great areas in the Crystal Palace; the spanning of great voids is the Brooklyn Bridge; and the reaching of great heights in the Eiffel Tower. Nothing which came after them could remain entirely unaffected."
At midnight tonight an eclipse of the sun will begin on the moon and, of greater interest to inhabitants of the United States and Canada, an eclipse of the moon will commence on earth.

WASHINGTON, May 23 The Soviet and Israeli Ambassadors to the United States have held several unpublicized meetings in Washington in recent months to discuss relations between their two countries, broken since 1967.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., May 23 Boris Dov Djerassi may be too heavy for acceptance by some graduate schools but he became No. 1 today in American hammer throwing this year with a meetrecord throw of 222 feet 6 inches during the 99th annual I.C.4-A outdoor track and field championships.

A group representing black and Hispanic construction workers made public yesterday several conditions for accepting a state proposal designed to end a dispute over the number of minority workers on a City College construction project.

Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, whose career as one of the nation's leading trainers apparently was ended five years ago with a decision to bar stalls for his horses in New York, may soon be in action again.

There is no reason to believe that Edward Kuznetsov, the 36-year-old author of "Prison Diaries," has ever met any of the 17 former Soviet citizens interviewed in Irina Kirk's "Profiles in Russian Resistance." Yet the books are intricately entwined. Kuznetsov and the others share a total disaffection from the Soviet system, an inability to conform and an overwhelming despair which, ultimately, led each of them to seek personal freedom in the West.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24-- A.J. Foyt has something in common with Jack Nicklaus. Both have won everything important two, three or four times. And now, in the same year that Nicklaus became the first golfer to win the Masters a fifth time, Anthony Joseph Fnyt Jr. will try to make it tomorrow as the first four-time winner of the Indianapolis 500.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 24--No one knew today which yacht was ahead in the Storm Trysail Club's annual 205-mile race to Block Island and back. It was known, however, that the leader and the 121 others were not sailing very fast in continued light winds.

There are probably more recipes for Hungarian goulash throughout the world than there are for sauerkraut, coq au vin and bouillabaisse--not to mention baked beans--put together. Actually, both a soup and a meat stew go by the name goulash. George Lang explains in his immensely edifying book, "The Cuisine of Hungary" (Atheneum, 1971), that originally a gulyas was a shepherd's dish made with meat cooked with onions until all the liquid disappeared.

ELIZABETH--The fiery destruction of more than a halfmillion cans of Bon want soup is scheduled to begin here this week, nearly four years after the Federal Government impounded the cans following a man's death from botulism.

The city administration is completing its first "prospectus" on its finances, a highly detailed compilation that Corporation Counsel W. Bernard Richland says will show the city's "magnificent resources, enormous potential and imperishable qualities."

The marriage of Hilary Jane Moynahan to Thomas Bailey Murphy took place in the Convent Chapel of St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., yesterday afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. Phillip Miller Pappas of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolyn Pappas, to Donald James Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Gibson Lewis of Temple, Tex.

TOTOWA--Yardley, the 105-year-old British-born cosmetics company that made the scent of Lavender famous, is constantly introducing new lines and dropping others. The reason is simple, for in this business, like fashions, consumers' tastes change from season to season.

Every five years or so, someone writes the obituary of club life in New York. A series of raids by Federal, county and local law enforcement officers in Newark yesterday led to the seizure of 10 pounds of heroin with a street sales value of several million dollars, and the arrest of five men.
VALETTA, Malta, May 24 (AP)--The Government is abolishing the nobility and establishing its own awards for acts of bravery and distinguished service.

The legal battles followin the Muhammad Ali-Chuck Wepner free-for-all in March are certainly more interesting than their fight was. Within a week Al Braverman, Wepner's manager, filed a suit against Perez for allowing ". . . deliberate and flagrant fouling by Ali" Braverman further asserted...
John Clifford and a small group of dancers from the Los Angeles Ballet were guests of the New York Philharmonic for the Promenades concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night.

The heat and humidity yesterday failed to put a damper on the enthusiasm of thousands of bicycle riders who took part in the fourth annual 24-hour Pepsi-Cola Bicycle Marathon in Central Park.

Belatedly but resolutely, 31 states are pushing to preserve their open spaces and farmlands, which are being gobbled up throughout the nation by urbanization and suburbanization at the rate of 1.5 million acres a year.

LOS ANGELES "Today the film composer is a star. More than onethird of a picture's success is due to the music. The audience doesn't know it is being turned on by the music, but a good score can grab an audience and hold it. I have seen weak performances helped enormously by music. Besides ordering the North Sea delicacy at the counters and tables, customers can buy the herring from a colorful wooden cart, complete with striped awning, that is the Dutch equivalent of the hot dog cart. Dutchmen eat raw herring as a between-meal snack.

They added, in a communique, that this would be combined with "further reduction in the average rate of inflation."

WASHINGTON, May 29 Terry Sanford, the president of Duke University and onetime Governor of North Carolina, became today the sixth Democrat to enter the 1976 Presidential race. He is the fourth entrant with a Southern accent and the first to make a confrontation with Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama the cen tral test of his candidacy.

Adrienne d'Albe Leichtle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Adrian Leichtle of Watertown Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to John Courtlandt Maxwell Jr. of Richmond, son of the late Mr. Maxwell and the late Genevieve Mangam Maxwell of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 29 Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that "a great deal of information" about the intelligence activities of the Federal Bureau of Investigation had already been provided to the Senate select committee that is examining the bureau's operations as part of an over-all inquiry into the Federal intelligence community.
LISBON, May 30 Portugal's leftist military rulers and the strong Socialist party reached an agreement tonight that could ease tensions threatening the provisional Government.
The scope of the extensive cutbacks proposed by Mayor Beame in his new budget were staggering to some of the out-of-towners visiting New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (Reuters) The United States has quietly increased its military presence in South Korea over the last year by an additional 4,000 men to the authorized level of 42,000, United States officials said today.

LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) Britain plans to give the Caribbean island of Anguilla a large measure of self government without formally cutting its constitutional link with the Associated State of St. KittsNevis-Anguilla, the Foreign Office announced today.
WASHINGTON, May 30 The Administration published today revised projections of the nation's economy for 1976 and the rest of the decade that were a little less gloomy than those issued last February.

WASHINGTON, May 30 Retired Maj. Gen. Edward G. Lansdale said tonight that in late 1961, Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, acting on behalf of President Kennedy, ordered him to prepare contingency plans to depose Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba.

Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy Sr., president emeritus of Adelphi University, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in the Fort Pierce (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Fort Pierce.

WASHINGTON, May 30 Russell E. Train, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that "significant progress" had been made toward cleaning up the nation's air, but that there was "still a long way to go" before health-related primary standards on six pollutants were met in urban and industrial areas.

The proposal by Governor Carey's blue-ribbon panel of fiscal experts for a new state corporation to relieve New York City of its crushing burden of debt offers a ray of light in deepening municipal gloom.
TRENTON, May 3 (UPI) The minimum price of milk in New Jersey will rise two cents a gallon on Sunday, the State Agriculture Department announced today.

Roy Roberts, a film actor who was reputed to have appeared in close to 1,000 films in a career lasting more than 40 years, died Wednesday evening in St. Vincent's Hospital, Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.
DEVON, Pa., May 30 Stillmeadow Farm's The Crimson Tide won the intermediate jumper championship at the Devon Horse Show today and Melanie Smith wasn't at all surprised.

ALBANY, May 30 Placed by their own leader in a position where they must share some responsibility for city services cut or curbed because of a constricted budget, the seven Republican Senators from New York City have started to feel some pressure. But most of them insist they will stand fast for austerity.

Jon Hassell, a composer who has performed often with La Monte Young, gave the first of three concerts Thursday night at the Dia Art Foundation, 141 Wooster Street. The third and last is tonight at 8 o'clock.

WICHITA, Kan., May 30 Bishop Dolegiewicz of Montreal, Canada, upset an impressive field in the shot-put at the United States Track and Field Federation outdoor championships tonight, and also set a Canadian national record.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30 The Premier designated to resolve Lebanon's political crisis has encountered trouble in forming a cabinet. At the same time, new shooting incidents today closed shops and banks in Beirut after a day of relative order.
Two auction records were broken, a Napoleonic desk remained in France and a Frenchman, $96,000 poorer, strode away with 32 walking canes.

Carter Hawley Hale Stores, Inc., a major West Coast retailing organization, which also operates the Bergdorf Goodman specialty stores here, reported yesterday an 18.7 per cent drop in earnings for its first fiscal quarter on a sales increase of 5.8 per cent.

Inflation and budgetary stringency have quietly forced a more gradual increase in the number of flights for the manned shuttle rocket plane being developed by the United States under a $6-billion program.

The marriage of Lynne Robinson Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Martin Jr. of Darien, Conn., to George Tedesche Simon took place here last evening. Criminal Court Judge Shirley R. Levittan performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. Carol Simon, mother of the bridegroom.

FORT INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., May 30--As the third contingent of Indochinese refugees began arriving here today, the civilian machinery to prepare them for eventual status as resident aliens was gathering speed.

GENEVA, May 30 Sixty-five nations today ended a fourweek review of how well the five-year-old treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons has worked. Most of them registered strong dissatisfaction.

BRUSSELS The position of France at the current NATO summit is both anomalous and important. It is anomalous because the French have not been members of the NATO military organization since they withdrew from its integrated command structure and expelled its headquarters eight years ago. But it is important because the French still consider themselves signatories to and loyally obligated by the North Atlantic Alliance.

Albert S. Pacetta, who served as deputy fire commissioner and as Markets Commissioner here in the Wagner administration, was indicted by a Queens County grand jury yesterday on a charge of asking for a bribe to influence his decision as a member of the New York State Human Rights Appeals Board.
ARLINGTON, Tex., May 30 Two well-placed hits in the ninth inning tonight gave the Rangers a 6-5 victory over the Yankees after Texas had rallied three times to tie the game.

ATLANTA, May 30 Miller Barber, a 44-year-old pro who is bald and rotund and who has perhaps the most unorthodox swing on the professional circuit, shot a 64 today to share the lead with Hale Irwin after the second round of the Atlanta Golf Classic.

Looking closely, through the eyes of a brilliant historian, we can envision wind-powered galleons cross-haired in the periscopes of prowling nuclear submarines.

Hearst, pleaded guilty here today to a misdemeanor charge of drug possession and was placed on probation for four months with the understanding that the charge would be dismissed if she completed probation satisfactorily.

One of the nation's leading credit-rating agencies dropped Connecticut's rating a notch yesterday, mainly because the state has a projected $74-million budget deficit and plans to make it up through shortterm borrowing. TKENTON, May 30, (UPI) Governor Byrne has signed a bill designed to protect children from unsafe amusement rides.

The Stuttgart Ballet's version of "Romeo and Juliet" is a production for the tired business man and balletomane alike. At its first performance this season Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the ballet again proved to be an exciting spectacle. This is theater in the best sense.

With its third and last program at the New York State Theater on Thursday night the New York City Ballet concluded its Ravel Festival, although, of course like its predecessors, this program as scheduled will be given a total of four performances. It was the best of the three programs perhaps markedly the best but it seems doubtful whether this festival can provide much of value for either Ravel or New York City Ballet.

The New York Knicks announced yesterday the signing of George McGinnis in defiance of the National Basketball Association constitution. The surprise move violated the league's bylaws and its draft rules.

Emile E. Bugnon, who served for 39 years as chief of police of Wood-Ridge, N.J., died Thursday at his home there. He was 79 years old.

On a political visit to New York a few months ago, former Gov. Terry Sanford of North Carolina shrewdly evaluated his chances in the competition for the Presidency. Nevertheless, he has now formally declared himself in the race, indicating that whatever the temperature of the water, he does not feel frozen out.

A State Supreme Court justice who this month ruled that a cable-television moderator had seduced but not raped a college student yesterday sent the man to jail for one year for trespassing in the apartment where the assignation occurred and for escaping from the police after his arrest.

Amax, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement by which the Standard Oil Company of California will purchase 5.9 million shares of Amax common stock for $333.4-million in cash and preferred shares of a Socal subsidiary.
A 63-year-old security guard in a bookstore on the Jamaica campus of St. John's University was shot and killed yesterday while attempting to foil a robbery, the police reported.

Foster, the Oakland School Superintendent, with cyanide-tipped bullets on Nov. 6, 1973.

But nowadays, the international traffic in plants the kind you simply look at or, if you must bore them, talk to is so intense that it threatens the survival of some of the world's most beautiful and interesting species.

ROME, May 30 (UPI) Raul Ramirez, playing methodical tennis, upset top-seeded Bjorn Borg, 6-4, 6-3, and gained the semifinals of the $120,000 Italian tennis championships today.
HARRISBURG, Pa., May 30 The hostess and a guest at a midday card party identified Joseph Kallinger in court here today as the intruder who bound and robbed them last Dec. 3.
VIENTIANE, Laos, May 30 Top officials throughout the Laotian administration are resigning under pressure from demonstrators as the Pathet Lao increasingly solidify their control over the Government.

BIRMINGHAM, May 30 The United States Steel Corporation and Federal air pollution officials reached a compromise tonight in the running dispute over how to cleana up the big manufacturer's Birmingham operation.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) The Justice Department says it will file suit to block the proposed sale of the Miller Printing Machinery Company of Pittsburgh to Gutehoffnungshutte Aktienverein of West Germany.
HONG KONG, May 30 (Agence France-Presse) The new authorities of South Vietnam have banned the burning of books and publications deemed "decadent and reactionary," the Saigon radio reported today.

The New York Knicks announced yesterday the signing of George McGinnis in defiance of the National Basketball Association constitution. The surprise move violated the league's bylaws and its draft rules.
WASHINGTON, May 30 Prices farmers received for raw agricultural products climbed 5 per cent from April 15 to May 15, the second consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

BRUSSELS, May 30 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany declared today that the Atlantic alliance was threatened "more by the world economic situation than in any particular geographical area," and called for more coordination in economic policies.

OCEANPORT, N.J., May 31--Coraggioso, with a powerful sweep down the stretch, overhauled Bird Island and Ringmistress today to win the 41st running of the $25,000-added Regret Handicap at Monmouth Park, before a crowd of 18,058.

WASHINGTON--President Ford will not wear makeup, William J. Baroody Jr. will not walk over his grandmother on behalf of the President. The formal title of Mr. Ford's 1976 campaign organization Will not disguise the identity of the candidate.

When school ends, their children will take off for two months in the country or at the shore. But few of the regular camp checklists will include a sentence of "necessary items" such as this one: "Braces, crutches, prosthesis, orthopedic shoes and wheelchairs must be in good condition."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP)--President Ford will make public next week his decision on controversial new Federal anti-discrimination rules regarding women in school and college sports. The stock market finished almost unchanged last week in continued active trading despite an abundance of favorable economic developments.

MENDHAM--After commuting to New York for 17 years, 43-year-old Gerald Supple resigned his $50,000 job with a prestigious Wall Street investment house two years ago and opened a bicycle shop in nearby Flanders.

KINGS POINT, L.I., May 31--Larry Duttweiler of Plainadge and Robert Will of Lynbrook posted impressive double victories and Union- dale won the team title for the fourth straight year today in the Nassau County scholastic track and field championships at the Kings Point field.

WASHINGTON--President Ford's decisions last week to raise the special fee on imported oil by $1 a barrel and to start phasing out price controls on some domestic oil supplies have a three-fold purpose: to impress on other major oil-importing countries that the United States will join them in conservation and other efforts to deal with the energy crisis; to reduce consumption at home, and to prod the Congress into action on a comprehensive energy program.

WASHINGTON, May 31--The prevailing mood here at the beginning of the summer is increasingly restless and partisan. The cattle are beginning to stir in the barn. The politicians are organizing for next year's elections, when many of them believe new leaders will be chosen, not only for the White House, but for the House and Senate as well.
JERUSALEM, May 31 (Reuters)--A hippodrome built by King Herod about 2,000 years ago has been discovered during excavations near Jericho, according to the archeologist involved.

THE symptoms have been familiar to travelers since time immemorial: diarrhea is an aspect of tourism universally experienced and minimally discussed. It has earned a plethora of sobriquets: Turista, Delhi Belly, Montezuma's Revenge, Poona Pooh's, G.I.'s, Cairo Crud. Yet its exact cause and cure have eluded scientists and left worried travelers at the mercy of old wives' tales, quacks and medical guesswork.

This switch, economists agree, will mean more accurate representation of price changes.

Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from earlier issues of the Book Review.

OYSTER, BAY, L.I., June 1 The New York Yacht Club has a problem with its Solution Trophy. At the end of the two-day annual spring regatta today, there was a tie for the top award between Charisma and Artemis. And the solution won't be found until rating certificates are checked, a lengthy process.

A New York woman who had a checking account at a major bank was shocked recently when the bank removed some funds from that account. The reason: Her payments on purchases made by using the bank's credit card were overdue.

The bigwigs in the Democratic National Committee have just given Madison Square Garden the once-over as a possible site for the party's Presidential convention next year. The choice seems to shake down to New York vs. Los Angeles, with New Orleans as a dark horse. Before making an unwise decision, we urge that the Democrats recall the (paraphrased) words of Fred Allen: "Los Angeles is a great place if you're an orange."

The adventures of Martha (conclusion): Several weeks ago we printed a letter from a reader who sent us a recipe for a noodle dish called Martha's Company Casserole. We printed a subsequent article establishing the creator of the dish (it was created more than 20 years ago) with an added note that we still did not know the identity of Martha.

The Supreme Court recently decided that even where they prevail, public-interest groups are not entitled to attorneys' fees unless the statute involved in the lawsuit provides for such payments. The decision applies to a substantial portion of public-interest litigation and is a major blow to a highly constructive legal movement. In recent years, public-interest lawyers have broken new ground in helping to define rights and in enforcing promises embedded in Federal and state legislation.

Five unions are withdrawing $14,350,000 in deposits from the First National City Bank to protest the bank's alleged role in bringing about the city's current cash-flow and budget crises, Victor Gotbaum, chairman of the Municipal Labor Committee, said yesterday.
